About LAPO MfB 





LAPO Microfinance Bank is an off-shoot of the Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO), a poverty-focused Non-Governmental Organization. The bank was incorporated in April 2007 and licensed to operate as a regulated State Microfinance Bank by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) in 2010. It became a National Microfinance Bank in 2012.

LAPO Microfinance bank is committed to financial inclusion, social and economic empowerment through the provision of easy access to responsive financial services to members of low-income households and owners of micro small and medium enterprises in the most sustainable manner.

Microfinance Finance Bank of First Choice 

LAPO Microfinance Bank’s vision for the future is to build a purpose-driven institution that will outlive its founders and stand as a model for sustainable financial inclusion and social empowerment in Nigeria and beyond.

To achieve this, we are committed to continually reshaping the narrative of microfinance by offering innovative, client-centric solutions that go beyond financial services—empowering individuals, households, and communities to rise above poverty.

All aspects of our operations carry equal weight as we work towards becoming one of the most impactful and professionally run financial institutions in Africa. Our goal is to uphold the culture of excellence, integrity, and empathy we are known for, while constantly delivering value to all stakeholders.

The engine behind our success is the dedication and resilience of every team member; a shared passion to make a difference, to exceed expectations, to serve with heart, and above all, to do things right the first time, every time.

For LAPO Microfinance Bank, we care deeply about our clients and their journeys to financial freedom; about our people and their growth; and about our partners and the futures we’re building together. We remain committed to inclusive prosperity and a better tomorrow for all.

History 

The story of LAPO Microfinance Bank is a remarkable testament to what can be achieved through resilience, vision, and a deep-rooted commitment to social impact. Founded in the late 1980s by Dr. Godwin Ehigiamusoe as a non-governmental organization in response to the rising poverty levels in Nigeria, LAPO has grown into one of Africa’s most respected microfinance institutions—proof that it is indeed possible to thrive while serving the underserved.

In 2010, LAPO transitioned into a licensed state microfinance bank and obtained a national license from the Central Bank of Nigeria in 2012, expanding its capacity to deliver inclusive financial services across the country. Over the years, the Bank has won several national and international recognitions for excellence in microfinance, financial inclusion, and gender empowerment. Today, LAPO operates through a vast network of over 500 branches across Nigeria, reaching millions of clients with innovative savings, loan, and insurance products designed to uplift low-income households and small business owners.

Rating

LAPO Microfinance Bank remains firmly committed to delivering strong value to its stakeholders—clients, employees, communities, and investors. Its financial sustainability and responsible banking practices have earned it consistent recognition by reputable ratings agencies. Agusto & Co. has consistently rated LAPO as an “A” category institution for its creditworthiness, operational soundness, and risk management framework. These ratings reinforce the Bank’s reputation as a secure and forward-thinking institution within Nigeria’s financial landscape.

With a legacy of empowerment, prudent financial management, and a culture of excellence, LAPO Microfinance Bank continues to blaze the trail in inclusive finance, proving that business success and social impact can go hand in hand.

RECOGNITION AND AWARDS

LAPO Microfinance Bank has, over the years, been recognized both locally and internationally for its outstanding contributions to financial inclusion, excellence in microfinance, innovation in service delivery, and strong operational performance.

In 2024, LAPO MfB was awarded the Best Microfinance Bank at 2nd Annual International Financial Inclusion Conference

In 2024, LAPO MfB was awarded as the Peak Performing Microfinance Bank of the Year

In 2024, LAPO MfB was awarded as the Microfinance Bank of the Decade at BusinessDay Banks and Other Financial Institutions (BAFI) Awards

OPERATIONAL PERFORMANCE

LAPO Microfinance Bank has consistently demonstrated strong operational performance, underpinned by sound corporate governance, robust risk management frameworks, and a deep commitment to financial inclusion. The Bank’s business model is built on sustainability, client impact, and operational efficiency, enabling it to maintain steady growth while reaching underserved communities across Nigeria.

With a network of over 500 branches and service outlets across 34 states and the Federal Capital Territory, LAPO has successfully scaled its operations without compromising service quality. The Bank continues to deliver a diverse portfolio of microcredit, savings, and insurance products tailored to the needs of low-income earners, small-scale entrepreneurs, and women-led businesses.

LAPO’s operational strength is reflected in its expanding client base, high portfolio quality, and impressive loan recovery rates. The Bank has invested heavily in technology-driven solutions to enhance service delivery, data accuracy, and customer experience. Its well-trained staff, coupled with strong internal controls, ensure compliance, transparency, and consistent delivery of value at all levels.

The institution’s ability to maintain operational excellence while achieving social impact is a key differentiator, making LAPO Microfinance Bank a reference point for best practices in the microfinance sector.



BRANCH NETWORK

LAPO Microfinance Bank operates one of the largest and most accessible microfinance networks in Nigeria, with over 500 branches strategically located across 34 states and the Federal Capital Territory. This widespread presence enables us to reach underserved and remote communities, bringing essential financial services closer to those who need them most.

Our branches are designed to reflect LAPO’s commitment to client convenience, personalized service, and financial empowerment. Each location is staffed by dedicated professionals who understand the local context and are trained to offer responsive, inclusive, and value-driven banking services. Through this expansive network, LAPO continues to bridge the gap between the unbanked population and formal financial services, contributing significantly to Nigeria’s financial inclusion goals.

BUSINESS OPERATIONS

LAPO Microfinance Bank’s business operations are built on the foundation of promoting financial inclusion and empowering low-income individuals, particularly women and small business owners. The Bank offers a range of tailored financial services, including microcredit, savings, and microinsurance products, all designed to support enterprise development, household stability, and economic growth. With a vast operational presence across 34 states and the FCT, LAPO delivers its services through a network of over 500 branches, supported by field agents and digital platforms to ensure accessibility and efficiency.

Guided by principles of transparency, ethical lending, and client protection, LAPO integrates financial literacy and customer engagement into its daily operations. The Bank continues to leverage technology and data-driven insights to improve service delivery, streamline internal processes, and expand its outreach. Its commitment to social impact and operational excellence has positioned LAPO as a benchmark institution in Nigeria’s microfinance sector.

OPERATION ASSUMPTIONS

Low-income people are too disadvantaged to benefit from existing credit schemes operated by government and formal financial institutions.

The poor are not necessarily lazy.

An improvement in the socio-economic situation of the poor would take place if financial services were added to support their physical labor and skills.

Small groups have tremendous influence on cooperating individuals.

Poverty is reinforced by problems such as too large family size, malnutrition, ignorance and diseases.

Women and children are relatively more victims of poverty.

Board of Directors

Chairman

Dr. Godwin Eseiwi Ehigiamusoe: Dr. Godwin Eseiwi Ehigiamusoe, PhD, FCIBN, is a distinguished microfinance practitioner and social entrepreneur renowned for championing financial inclusion and empowering low-income communities. He is the founder of Lift Above Poverty Organisation (LAPO), established in the late 1980s as a response to the adverse effects of the Structural Adjustment Programme in Nigeria. Starting with just N100 loans to three individuals, LAPO has evolved into a formidable development institution offering a wide range of financial services—including microfinance, micro-insurance, and micro-leasing—positively impacting millions of Nigerians. His leadership also extended to establishing LAPO Microfinance Bank in Nigeria and Sierra Leone, with the latter issuing the first-ever corporate bond in that country.

Over the years, Dr. Ehigiamusoe has significantly contributed to the development of Nigeria’s microfinance policy and regulatory framework, training numerous practitioners and regulators locally and internationally. His academic background includes degrees in Sociology and a PhD in Policy and Development Studies, with a dissertation focused on financial inclusion. He is a certified microfinance practitioner and has completed various executive education programs.

He has received numerous awards such as the Grameen Foundation’s Award for Excellence in Microfinance and the Schwab Foundation’s Outstanding Social Entrepreneur for Africa. A published author of several books and memoirs, he continues to be a strong advocate for human development. Married with children and grandchildren, he remains active in faith-based networks and is committed to creating life-changing opportunities for low-income households.

She is a certified microfinance professional and a member of several professional bodies, including the Nigerian Bar Association and the Chartered Institute of Bankers.

Since joining LAPO Microfinance Bank in 2007, she has risen to the position of Company Secretary and Chief Compliance Oﬃcer in 2019.

DIRECTOR, BRANDING & COMMUNICATIONS

Oluremi Akande is a seasoned marketing and communications professional with over 17 years of experience in advertising, brand strategy, research, and media consultancy. He has held managerial roles at leading firms such as Dali Communications, Phillips Consulting, and Skye Bank Plc.

Oluremi holds a Master's in Diplomacy & Strategic Studies from the University of Lagos and a Bachelor's in Linguistics & Nigerian Languages from the University of Ilorin. He is a certified Chartered Marketer (UK), a Registered Advertising Practitioner (APCON), and a certified microfinance practitioner.

Since joining LAPO Microfinance Bank in 2019, he has served as the Head of Corporate Communications and Branding.





CHIEF FINANCE OFFICER

Mr. Emmanuel Igiehon holds a Bachelor of Science in Education from the University of Benin, an MBA from the National Open University of Nigeria, and a Post Graduate Diploma in Accounting from the University of Lagos.

He is a Fellow of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Nigeria (ICAN) and a certified microfinance practitioner. With certifications from ACCA and extensive international training, he has expertise in financial planning and microfinance.

Mr. Igiehon joined LAPO Microfinance Bank in 2004, and after serving in various roles, he became the Chief Finance Oﬃcer (CFO) in July 2020.

INTRODUCTION  
LAPO Microfinance Bank Limited is a Bank with the Mission and Vision of Improving lives 
through provision of affordable credit facilities to economically active person s in business. In 
providing these services, LAPO MFB has developed a number of products to meet the needs of 
her ever increasing clients. 
This product manual is a document that highlights the features of LAPO MFB products and 
services and methodology used in deploying these products to identified targets. 
BOARD/ EXECUTIVE CREDIT COMMITTEE FUNCTIONS 
A. Constitution 
 
The Executive Credit Committee (the “Committee”) is appointed by the Boards of 
Directors of LAPO Microfinance Bank Limited (“the Microfinance Bank” ) to act on behalf 
of the Board in fulfilling assigned responsibilities in the terms of  reference set in this 
charter.  
B. Purpose 
 
The purpose of the Committee shall be to; 
 Ensure and manage credit and lending strategies and objectives of the Bank, 
 Oversee t he credit management  of the Bank, including reviewing internal credit 
policies and portfolio limits as approved by the Board; 
 Review the quality and performance of the Bank’s credit portfolio;  
 Formulate and recommend credit policies of the Bank to the Boa rd for approval 
and ensure that same is communicated to Management for implementation 
 
C. Composition 
 
The Committee shall be composed of Executive Directors and relevant Senior 
Management Staff of the Bank including the Managing Director who shall be the 
Chairman of the Committee.   
 
D. Membership 
 
Membership of the Committee shall be composed of the following: 
 
 Managing Director (Chairman) 
 Chief Finance Officer (CFO)

 Head, Corporate Services Division 
 Head, Business Support Division 
 Head, Corporate Secretariat, Legal & Compliance Department 
 Head, Corporate Planning Department 
 Head, Strategy Department 
 Head, Risk Management Department 
 Head, Internal Audit & Control Department 
 Head, Credit Department 
 Head, Management information system 
 Head, Operations Department 
 Head, Treasury and Creditors Relationship Management  
 
E. Meetings 
a. Frequency, Participation and Agenda 
 
 Meetings shall be held once in every month. 
 The meetings will be chaired by the Managing Director or in his/her absence a 
Designate; 
 All members of the Committee shall have the right to attend and participate in the 
deliberations at the Executive Credit Committee meeting.  
 The Secretary to the Committee shall prepare the agenda in consultation with the 
Chairman. 
 
F. Notice of Meetings 
 
The notice of the committee meeting and relevant documents for deliberation shall be 
circulated by the Secretary to the Committee members prior to the meeting.  
 
G. Quorum 
The Executive Credit Committee shall form a quorum by simple majority of members 
present at the meeting. 
Resolutions by the Executive Credit Committee shall be passed by simple majority. In 
case of equality of votes, the presiding Chairman of the Committee shall have a casting 
vote.

H. Secretarial tasks and other assistance 
The office of t he Head, Credit Department shall be the secretariat for the Executive 
Credit Committee.    
The Secretary to the Committee shall prepare and keep minutes of deliberations and 
decisions at the meetings. 
The Secretary in collaboration with the Head, Operation s D ivision shall prepare and 
present a report of activities and deliberations of the Committee to the Board Credit 
Committee.  
 
I. Responsibilities and Duties 
 
The Executive Credit Committee of the Bank shall be responsible for implementing the 
credit risk st rategy and credit risk policies approved by the board of directors and 
develop procedures that include identifying, measuring, monitoring and controlling 
credit risk.  
The Committees responsibilities include the following: 
 
Implement and control the Bank’s  overall credit risk appetite as approved by the Board; 
and as documented in the target market plan through the target market/risk acceptance 
criteria and concentration limits; 
 Recommend for Board approval, risk appetite, risk limits, risk tolerances and credit policy 
guidelines applicable in LAPO MFB. 
 
 Providing required support to the Board of Directors to guide the definition of the 
bank's credit risk appetite and ensure exposures are created in line with the 
approved appetite. 
 Consider write-offs presented by Management Committee for Board approval. 
 Ensuring adherence to the credit policy through exception monitoring.  
 Review exception reports and determine appropriate actions for policy breaches. 
 Ensure appropriate provisions for loan losses are made. 
 Initiate and review the report of validation of delinquent account and provisioning 
status.  
 Review the Bank’s Credit Portfolio (and material sub-portfolio) on a monthly basis. 
 Review all credit and related policies and key processes. 
 Make recommendations to the Board in line with approved Credit Risk 
Management Policy. 
 Review the Bank’s compliance with regulatory requirements on credit issues as 
well as compliance with internal code of conduct and ethical rules on lending.

SECTION ONE 
1.0 LOAN PRODUCTS 
1.1 CLASSIFICATION OF LAPO LOAN PRODUCTS 
LAPO MFB has a number of p roducts sold to its clients and these products can be classified into 
5 major products. 
i. Group 
LAPO MFB micro loan is small loans for small businesses, with l oan size of between ₦ 30,000- 
₦500,000. Micro loans are disbursed in virtually all LAPO MFB branches, using the group 
methodology after a thorough Pre-loan training to targeted clients.  
ii. Agricultural 
Agricultural financing is designed to help farmers achiev e better results through the provision 
of agricultural loans. Loan size is between ₦30,000- ₦5,000,000 
iii.  Individual  
Individual loans comprise of Small Business Loan (SBL), Supporting Female Entrepreneurs 
(SUFEN) loan, Consumer loan, Small and Medium Enterp rise loan (SME). Social Impact Fund for 
LAPO Entrepreneurs (SIFLEN), Business Succes s Loan (BSL) , Faith-Based Loan. The Micro, Small 
and Medium Enterprises [MSME] sector has been recognized as the engine of growth of any 
developing nation. As such, LAPO MF B as a foremost Microfinance bank has provided th ese 
products to serve the class of business es that require higher loans than the Micro Loan Class. 
LAPO MFB Individual Loans ranges between ₦100,000 - ₦100,000,000.

iv. Housing 
Housing loan is designed to provide affordable credit facility to both existing and new clients 
who desire to either build houses, improve on their present houses or business premises. The 
loan is structured to acco mmodate low income earners who do not have access to housing 
finance due to the fact that they may not be able to provide the necessary security to access 
the credit facility. The loan can be accessed by both salary earners and business persons who 
meet the eligibility criteria. Loan amount ranges between ₦100,000 to ₦5,000,000. 
v. Clean Energy  
Clean Energy Loans were developed to preserve the environment and protect our clients from 
the inhalation of carbon  present through naked flames (Candles and Kerosene Lamp) and 
unclean cooking fuels (firewood and charc oal). To achieve this LAPO MfB entered into 
partnership with a number of Energy Renewable Companies to serve its esteemed clients and 
preserve the environment. 
1.2 METHODOLOGY OF LAPO PRODUCTS 
LAPO MfB deploys Products and services through 2 methods  
i. Group Methodology  
Group Methodology involves formation and administration of a group led by a Union Leader 
and assisted by Union secretary . A Group consists of between 5 -60 persons, with similar or 
different business types. The group provides guarantee for members and is managed by a Client 
Support Officer (CSO) who meets with a Maximum of 5 groups daily.  
ii. Individual Methodology 
The individual Methodology involves singular disbursement of credit to clients without the use 
of group guarantee but individual guarantees. With this methodology, individuals who were not 
able to access loans under group methodology as a result of the size of their business or the 
fact that they are not inclined to belong to groups are able to access loan s after meeting the 
eligibility criteria. This methodology however exposes the Bank to higher risk.

1.4   LAPO MfB Enterprise Financing Exclusion List  
i. Production or trade in any product or activity deemed illegal under any applicable laws 
of Federal Republic of Nigeria. 
ii. Production or trade in weapons and ammunitions’ 
iii. Production or trade in alcoholic beverages (excluding beer and wine) 
iv. Production or trade in tobacco 
v. Gambling, casinos and equivalent enterprises 
vi. Trade in wildlife or wildlife products regulated under cities 
vii. Production or trade in radioactive materials 
viii. Production or trade in or use of unbounded asbestos fibers 
ix. Purchase of logging equipment for use in primary tropical moist forest. 
x. Production or trade in pharmaceuticals subject to international phase outs or bans. 
xi. Production or trade in pesticides/herbicides subject to international phase outs or bans. 
xii. Drift net fishing in the marine environment using nets in excess of 2.5 km. in length. 
xiii. Production or activities involving harmful or exp loitative forms of forced labour/harmful 
child labour. 
xiv. Commercial logging operations for use in primary tropical moist forest. 
xv. Production or trade in products containing PCB

1.6 DEBT –SERVICE RATIO (DSR) 
What is Debt Service Ratio (DSR)? Debt Service Ratio (DSR) measures the ability of the 
client to repay his/her monthly installmen t from the business monthly net profit. This is 
usually derived from cash flow-based lending analysis. The bank debt service ratio is 
between ≥3.7 to ≥1.4. The formula for calculating the ratio is   Repayment Capacity  
                                                                                                                Monthly Installment   
 
i. Small and Medium Enterprise (SME): ≥ 1.4 (not more than70% of repayment capacity) 
ii. Small Business Loan (SBL):           ≥1.4(not more than 70% of repayment capacity)                                                   
iii. SUFEN Loan:                ≥ 1.4(not more than 70% of repayment capacity) 
iv. DBN Loan:             ≥1.4 (not more than 70% of repayment capacity)  
v. BSL Loan:             ≥1.4 (not more than 70% of repayment capacity) 
vi. Housing loan (Old Clients):           ≥2.5 (not more than 40% of repayment capacity) 
vii. Housing loan (New Clients):               ≥ 3.7 (not more than 27% of repayment capacity)

1.7 RIGHT OF SET OFF  
For all loans,  the bank is entitled to right of set  off, using client savings as stated in 
clause 3 in declaration section of account opening booklet. 
1.8      LOAN CANCELLATION 
Where a client no longer has need fo r loan already disbursed to him /her and wishes to 
return the loan, the client is allowed to d o so. However, the client will be required to 
pay whatever interest has accrued for the period the loan was with him/her. 
 
1.8.1   Loan Cancellation Procedure 
i. Branch Manager is the ONLY staff authorised to carry out this transaction. 
ii. Client informs the CSO /Branch Manager of his or her intention to cancel/return 
the loan 
iii. Branch Manager Checks Core Banking System to determine if any interest has 
accrued for the period the loan was with the client. 
iv. Branch Manager informs the client of the total amount to be re paid, i.e principal 
loan amount and interest (If any) 
v. Client pays the repayment amount into the Branch account and presents teller 
to the Branch Manager. 
1.9   PROCEDURE FOR PERFECTING DEED OF HYPOTHECATION 
i. The form is printed out from the system and any o f the credit committee members takes 
the document to the client’s business place to complete the ‘Description of the 
Hypothecated goods’ during verification. 
ii. Goods to be listed in the deed of hypothecation shall include both current and fixed 
assets relating to the business. 
iii. This document is reviewed with the client so that he/she understands the content and 
implication of the document. 
iv. On NO ACCOUNT should this document be filed in the client’s file without filling and 
listing the hypothecated goods and assets 
v. Security: Deed of hypothecation is for all loan size, but no longer needs to be stamped by 
the clients in court before disbursement

1.11 PROCEDURE FOR KEEPING CHEQUE LEAFLETS WITH ACCOUNTANT 
i. Manager collects blank cheque leaflets from guarantor on the day of disbursement. 
ii. Guarantor MUST write ‘pay LAPO Microfinance bank ONLY’ behind the cheque leaflet 
and sign before giving them t o the MBM. This is to prevent any staff from fraudulently 
withdrawing using the cheque leaflets. 
iii. Guarantor is to sign the cheque lodgment register when cheque is lodged. 
iv. Manager enters the cheque lodg ment register for the guarantor  to sign; thereafter 
manager signs his/her column and gives the register to the compliance for vetting.  
v. Compliance officer verifies that the procedure has been perfected, signs his/her column 
and hands over the cheque leaflets and register to accountant.

1.12   SAVINGS WITHDRAWAL/ADJUSTMENT PROCEDURE 
i. The client must be present in the office to be able to withdraw savings. 
ii. Cash withdrawal can be carried out by the client by presenting a withdrawal slip or 
cheque leaflet. 
iii. Client can only withdraw from their account if they are saving voluntarily. 
iv. In carrying out savings withdrawal and loan adjustment, MBM and ICO are to ensure 
that the client maintains a savings balance that is commensurate with the loan 
balance throughout the loan tenure. 
v. In cases of savings adjustment for loan repayment, the client must be in  the office to 
sign the transaction. 
vi. Where the client is not personally present in the office for this transaction, the 
manager and compliance officer will put a call through to the client to confirm the 
transaction and thereafter the MBM and CSO will  sign their columns in the savings 
withdrawal register after the compliance officer has vetted the balance and 
transaction confirmed. 
vii. A call log register is maintained in the branch to this effect to record all calls made to 
any customer for monitoring purpose.  
viii. The register format is S/N, date call was made, caller’s name, customer called, 
customer’s phone no, purpose/reason(s) for calls, time of call, call duration, caller’s 
sign.  
ix. Any savings withdrawal/adjustment done without following due process and 
approval will be refunded back by the MBM and compliance officer in the event of 
any misappropriation arising from breach of policy.

1.13   DELINQUENCY PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT 
Every loan is treated as delinquent if not repaid in due time. It is reminded that t he loan 
shall be 100% repaid (principal + interest) and that the quality of the portfolio falls 
under the CSO and MBM and it is their joint responsibility. It is reminded that the CSO 
and the MBM should look for a way to avoid acceleration of delinquency a nd should try 
to have the client repay the loan instead. 
For the avoidance of doubt, it is emphasized that the CSO and BM should act tactfully 
and in responsible manner towards delinquent client, his relatives and the guarantors.  
Generally, it is the duty  of each CSO to check each day before the close of business for 
his/her clients who did not pay, call and visit the client to inquire about the missed 
repayment. The CSO should clearly communicate that LAPO MFB will take action, but 
should not overplay his /her hand and upset the client. The CSO should report his/her

1.14 LOAN RESTRUCTURING/RESCHEDULING POLICY 
All loans created from the bank's liabilities will be regarded as internal debt owed to the 
bank by its clients. They are risk assets which are obligatory for the bank to efficiently 
protect from default and possible loss. Regulatory authorities require micr ofinance banks

Document Control  
            Reference: LAPOMFB-OP-DOC-PM/60 
            Version No: 6.0 
            Page: 30 of 282 
 
 
 
 
                                                  PRODUCT MANUAL 
 
30 | P a g e  
INTERNAL USE 
 
not only to allow windows for loan rescheduling at an agreed cost but to make 100% 
provision for all rescheduled loans [CBN guidelines for microfinance banks (MFBs) in 
Nigeria]. 
 
i. Restructured loans are renegotiated or modified loans to eithe r lengthen or 
postpone the original scheduled installment payments, or substantially alter the 
original terms of the loans.  Restructured loans shall include refinanced loans i.e. 
loans disbursed to enable repayment or part repayment of prior loans that was  past 
due.   
 
ii. A loan can be restructured or rescheduled for the following reasons; 
a. Client and LAPO Microfinance Bank Limited agreeing to vary the terms and 
conditions for repayment of the loan where there is significant change in the 
critical business operating conditions that may make future loan repayments 
by the client difficult to actualize.  
b. Due to an economic down turn or when repayment capacity is impaired 
owing to some unforeseen circumstances such as ill health, job loss, natural 
disaster, involuntary dislocation, etc. 
iii. No loan shall be restructured more than once. 
iv. No loan shall be restructured when the loan duration has not elapsed. 
v. Loan to be restructured shall be the total outstanding loan amount and interest due 
(principal plus interest) 
vi. Loan repayment amount after loan restructuring shall be restructured loan amount 
plus interest rate amount spread across the restructured loan duration 
vii. Restructured loan duration shall be 1-12 months. 
viii. A minimum interest rate of 2% reducing balance monthly (24% per  annum) on the 
outstanding amount and due interest shall apply. 
ix. A restructuring fee of 0.5% on the outstanding loan amount shall be charged by the 
Bank; this shall be a one -off payment, to be paid at the point of restructuring by the 
client. 
1.14.1 OPERATIONAL PROCEDURE FOR LOAN RESTRUCTURING/ RESCHEDULING 
i. Branch manager can only apply for loan restricting on behalf of the client when all other 
efforts to recover the loan has failed and it is established that the client shall be able to 
repay the outstanding loan balance when rescheduled.

1.16   PROCEDURE FOR ENFORCEMENT OF POWER OF SALE OF COLLATERAL    
1.16.1 BACKGROUND   
This procedure shall apply to all secured loans in the LAPO Microfinance Bank. A secured 
loan is a loan that is secured by property or securities. Thi s is also known as collateral 
loan. In LAPO Microfinance Bank, a loan is secured where a client pledges collateral 
before accessing the loan.    
In a secured loan, where a client fails, refuses or neglects to repay principal and interest 
for two or more installments, the bank has the authority to take possession and dispose 
off the collateral pledged for the loan. That is, the bank is allowed to seize and dispose 
off the pledged collateral to settle the outstanding debt. This  can be done without 
recourse to court proceedings as the secured creditor does not need permission from a 
court to repossess and sell the collateral that was used to secure a loan. However, 
where landed property is involved, there is need to obtain court order before the bank 
can exerci se right of sale. The bank has a right to have access to the location of the 
pledged collateral; it however cannot break into a client’s business place or resident for 
collateral seizure.   
As a rule, every debt recovery measures must have been applied and  documented 
before the Bank can exercise the option of taking possession and sale of the collateral. 
This includes serving recovery letters on the client and guarantors and holding meetings 
to resolve the overdue situation. One exception to this is where a  fraud has been 
discovered and the bank need to move quickly to recover the whole debt or mitigate its 
loss from the client.     
1.16.2 CONDITIONS PROCEDENT BEFORE EXERCISE OF RIGHT OF POSSESSION 
i. All other recovery measures must have been deployed and fail ed to recover the 
overdue amount. 
ii. The availability of the items must be ascertained. 
iii. Meeting of the CIM , Branch Manager and Client Support Officer to take decision 
whether to exercise the right of possession after review of all documents and

iv. Where the collateral is the client’s residential home or an item in the residential 
home, a meeting must be held with the spouse to inform him o r her of the client’s 
obligation to the bank.     
 
         1.16.3 PROCEDURE FOR EXERCISE OF RIGHT OF POSSESSION 
i. The Branch Manager shall notify the client and guarantors in writing of the Bank’s 
intention to exercise its right of possession and sale of th e collateral pledged for 
the loan after two or more defaults in repayment of principal and interest.  
ii. The notice to the client and guarantors shall stipulate a period of one month grace 
within which the client or debtor and guarantors can liquidate the deb t own to the 
bank.  
iii. At the expiration of the period of grace, a team made of any three of Recovery 
Officer, Area Inspector, Branch Manager, and the Client Support Officer together 
with a law enforcement agent go to the location for recovery along with copi es of 
the loan agreements and document relating to the collateral.  
iv. The leader of the team requests to see the client or the spouse and inform them in 
clear terms of the purpose of the visit.  
v. The team leader who is either the Loan Recovery Officer or Area  Inspector shall list 
and document all the items taken over by the Bank from the client.  
vi. The document shall be signed by the client or the guarantor of the client and the 
team leader on behalf of the Bank.   
vii. The items must be carefully stored to avoid damage.  
viii. Where a client is recalcitrant there is need to report the conduct of the client in 
the nearest police station.   
 
1.16.4 CODE OF CONDUCT FOR STAFF DURING EMFORCEMENT OF RIGHT OF 
POSSESSION   
 
i. Ensure the process of possession is conducted in orderly and peaceful manner.  
ii. Avoid all forms of body contact with the client or act that may result to physical 
combat between the client and bank staff.  
iii. Ensure all items are registered in the collateral register.

1.16.5 PROCEDURE FOR EXERCISE OF RIGHT OF SALE OF COLATERAL:   
After exercise of right of possession, the client shall be informed in writing that the 
collateral shall be sold off at a given date if he or she fails to offset the outstanding debt. 
At the expiration of this notice, the following g uidelines shall be complied with by the 
Branch Manager to initiate processes to sell the collateral.     
i. An auctioneer shall be engaged to carry out the sales of the collateral items.  
ii. The client shall be given opportunity to bring any person he/she feels can buy the 
items. 
iii. The best possible prices should be gotten for the items.  
iv. Payment for every collateral item sold shall be made into the client’s account with 
the bank by the person purchasing the item.   
v. The counter copy of the deposit teller and acknowledgement of the receipt of the 
money paid shall be given to the buyer of the item.   
vi. The branch’s security officer shall verify the receipt and allow the buyer leave 
with the item.   
vii. Receipts for the items sold shall be filed in the client’s loan file by the Branch 
Manager. 
viii. At the end of the sales of the items, the outstanding debt shall be offset with the 
money realized from auction sales. 
ix. If the sales proceeds exceed the outstanding debt, the client shall be informed 
about the balance in his or her account. 
x. If the sales proceeds fall short of the outstanding debt, the client and the 
guarantors shall be informed to pay the balance of the debt.    
 
Where the collateral is a landed property the following procedure shall be complied    
with   
i. A court order shall be obtained for the purpose of the sale of the property.

1.17 AGGRESSIVE SALES 
Aggressive sale is  the continuous drive to improve the performance of every sales personnel 
(Client Support Officers, Relationship Managers and Branch Managers).  Where sales personnel 
is performing below the minimum level or above optimal level of per formance the supervisory 
personal are expected to concentrate in the monitoring of these staff for improvement in the 
case of those performing below the tolerable level or to manage the portfolio in the case of 
those above the optimal level. 
1.17.1 AGGRESSIVE SALES TRIGGER: 
Aggressive sales trigger starts from the monitoring level of sale’s force performance  by the 
supervisory staff. CSOs are advice to improve in their  performance in cases where they are 
under performing below set target. However, in the process of enforcing sale, staffs are advised 
never to take issues  personally if encounter a rude or forceful behav ior rather be  firm and 
friendly during the aggressive sale process.  
Abusive sales practice must be prohibited during an aggressive sale exercise; in  which an 
unethical/ unprofessional and unnecessary excessive trade  in order to generate commission 
and returns must not occurs where a sale representative has  the discretion to trade the 
account. 
In order words, on no account shall a staff take an u ndue advantage of customers lack of 
understanding, staff must disclose to client to satisfy the “Four P’s” – Prominence, placement,

1.17.3 ACTIONS TO BE TAKEN WHEN OPTIMAL LEVEL IS EXCEEDED: 
Where a  CSO or RM exceeds the maximum performance level the following actions shall be 
undertaken:  
i. A letter of commendation to be  given to the staff by the ZM and a copy of such 
commendation should be placed in the staff file.   
ii. The BM shall provide additional Support to the CSO or RM  for loan recovery exercise 
where PAR is exceeded. 
iii. BM shall escalate to the Area Loan Recovery officer to assist in loan recovery exercise. 
iv. The BM shall t ake part of the loan portfolio to CSO or RM with lower loan portfolio for 
proper management of the loan where loan portfolio is exceeded. 
v. Where all the CSOs are fully engaged the BM shall r equest for additional CSO to take over 
part of the loan portfolio for efficient management of the loans. 
vi. The Area Inspector is to escalate in the risk register and ensure the above actions are 
carried out by the Branch Manager.   
vii. Area Manager shall particularly  note CS Os and RMs with exceptional performance for  
reassignment for available higher responsibility as reward for them. 
 
Where a Branch exceeds the maximum performance level the following actions shall be 
undertaken: 
i. The CIM shall escalate this in the risk register. 
ii. The Area Manager shall notify the Zonal Manager the need to split the Branch where the 
loan portfolio exceeds the maximum portfolio. 
iii. The Zonal Manager shall apply for approval for the opening of a new Branch in the Area and 
part of the loan portfolio will be ceded to the new branch. 
iv. The Area Manager shall provide additional support to the branch for loan recovery exercise 
where the PAR is exceeded.  
v. The Area Loan Recovery Officer shall be notified to provide additional support to the Branch 
Manager.

1.18 ACCOUNT CLOSURE 
i. Account can only be closed on the client’s instruction given in writing. 
ii. The CSO interviews the customer to find out the reason for the request. If the reason has to 
do with dissatisfaction with the services of the bank, the CSO and MBM should try to prevail 
on the customer to continue the relationship. 
iii. If the client insists, the account can b e closed after stamping and verifying the signature on 
the letter to be same with the one in the signature card. 
iv. The customer is told to complete a withdrawal slip or write out a cheque for the account 
balance, less charges 
v. The unused cheque or withdrawal booklet, deposit booklet e.t.c are collected from the 
customer and all unutilized leaves are cancelled. 
vi. Teller pays the customer less charges (N300) and necessary entries are updated. 
vii. Account is closed in the system and customer’s Mandate file is marked ‘’ account closed’’ 
with red ink. Account closed register is updated. 
viii. Sometimes the bank may order the closure of a customer’s account for reasons resulting 
from fraud, long period of dormancy, court order, suspicious account transactions etc. 
Approval for cl osure must be obtained by the MBM from the appropriate approving 
authority. 
ix. After receiving approval to close the account the cash officer calculates the interest due to 
the customer (if an interest bearing account) and credits customers account with it be fore 
closure.

2.2  PRODUCT RATIONAL 
LAPO MFB offers Regular Loan to group members through affordable credit in order to reduce 
their dependency on money lenders.   
The objective of this loan is to improve the self -worth value of group member in his/her family 
as well as in the society by enabling them participate in income generating activities. This 
product would also enable the bank increase her client base and income.  
2.3 TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
i. The regular loan product is targeted at economically active poor, small and micro enterprise 
owners.  Tools used for the selection of target clients and group s are the participation form 
and score sheet. A group of borrowers who trade or live in the same locality. The CSO will 
provide a list of credible members for this purpose. 
ii. The above target market is characterized by traders with clearly identified regular cash flow 
streams. Members of this  target group mostly reside in the semi -urban, urban areas and 
they can also be found in rural areas where they perform trading activities. This target 
market are regularly faced with the need to finance their trade and family expenses; both 
nuclear and extended.

2.4  CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
The following are criteria that qualify clients for loan; 
i. Clients must be economically active men and women who own small and micro enterprise. 
ii. They must be physically and mentally able to manage a business of their own. 
iii. Clients should be in the same vicinity and self-selected. 
iv. Only those who have participated in the pre -loan training and understand LAPO -MFB 
policies and procedures are eligible for loan application. 
v. The business in which the client intends to inve st in should be an income generating and 
profitable business. The member should also have experience in the business. 
vi. The proposed loan amount should align with the product policies and conditions. 
vii. The business should be able to conveniently repay the week ly installment from the income 
generated by the business. 
viii. The surroundings, socio -political condition, mentality, intention and conduct of the union 
members/individual should be favorable for loan disbursement and repayment. 
 
2.5 REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION 
i. Clients are to open a savings account with LAPO MFB with a minimum of one thousand 
naira (N1, 000) (which also qualifies the client for a loan) and thereafter should be 
encouraged to save regularly to build up the savings.. 
ii. Participation form - This is filled to determine the client poverty score which pr e-qualifies 
the client for loan. This should be correctly and neatly filled and kept in the branch office by 
the manager. The CSO is responsible for filling this form. 
iii. Passport photograph- Five recent passport sized photographs will be needed. A copy will be 
affixed on the following documents: participation form, account opening booklet, mandate 
card, loan application form and client passbook. Subsequent loan application requires one 
passport.  
iv. Loan application forms- Completely and correctly filled loan application forms, duly signed 
by group members, union leader and secretary, CSO, branch manager and one external 
guarantor.  
v. One recent passport sized photograph from the external guarantor 
vi. Client passbook - This must be filled and signed by the CSO or manager whenever any 
financial transaction is carried out. 
vii. Pink card- This records the weekly summary of transactions and activities carried out in the 
union. This is to be filled by the CSO and signed by union leader and secretary.

2.6 OPERATIONAL METHODOLOGY 
i. After union formation, clients must complete the ir 2 to 4 weeks’ pre-loan training. During 
this period CSO fills participation form for clients, visit their house/business premises and 
subsequently fill loan form for eligible clients with their recent passport attached. 
ii. CSO will submit the client loan a pplication with his/her recommendation at least one week 
before proposed disbursement date to the Branch Manager/credit committee for approval. 
iii. The Branch Manager/credit committee will verify the application  through group/household 
visit and approve the loan application. 
iv. An external guarantor will sign the loan application form as a guarantor (preferably family 
member or spouse).  
v. The loan will be disbursed at the branch office by the branch manager/credit committee. 
vi. Disbursed forms will be filed in the uni on file and kept safely in a cabinet in the manager’s 
office. 
vii. All loans shall be subjected to credit bureau search before disbursement.  
viii. CSO must submit CSO due diligence checklist conducted for each union daily disbursement 
along with the loan application  and guarantor forms at least one week before 
disbursement. 
2.7 DISBURSEMENT METHODOLOGY 
After due diligence on loan application has been carried out, loan is approved and disbursed at 
the branch office following the outlined procedure;  
i. The branch manager  disburses the loan in regular branches, while th e credit committee 
disburses in mega branches. 
ii. Loan amount is disbursed into client’s savings account with LAPO MFB. Before direct 
transfer into client’s corresponding bank account bearing the same name on t he loan 
contract agreement form already endorsed by the client. 
iii. However, where the customer does not have a commercial bank account for the purpose of 
transfer, cheque can be issue for payment of such disbursement. 
iv. A copy of the loan agreement form and repayment schedule to be given to ALL clients at the 
point of disbursement.

2.8  REPAYMENT   METHODOLOGY          
i. Repayment is weekly and will be collected by the CSO during weekly group meetings. 
Repayment shall be paid in 24 weekly installments for 6 month s loan and 30 weekly 
installments for 8 months loan. 
ii. The first installment is expected to be paid 14 days after disbursemen t so that the                
borrower has time to invest the loan and generate inflows to be able to repay.  CSO 
responsibility is to  collect both elements of savings and loan installments, record the 
transaction in field collection sheet and client passbook.    
iii. The CSO is also expected to complete and sign on the union pink card and give to the union 
leader and secretary to also sign i f all entries are correct. The union secretary is also 
expected to complete the resolution note for the CSO and union leader to sign after 
reconciling the union transactions for the day. 
2.9 MONITORING 
i. The first monitoring officer to this loan is the CSO. Branch manager/credit committee also 
provides second level monitoring.

visit the client within 14 days after loan disbursement to ensure loan was invested in the 
business and not diverted. 
iii. The Area Inspector, Area, Zonal and Head Office team will provide additional monitoring. 
 
2.10 CLIENT DUTIES 
i. Promptly submit all necessary documents required for loan processing

v. Attend weekly/monthly meetings of the group on time. Lateness and absenteeism should 
be discouraged. 
vi. Make repayment without defaulting. 
vii. Make proper use of credit facility without diverting the loan 
viii. Resist the temptation to take multiple loans. 
ix. Take responsibility for fellow union member repayment in the event of default.

create wealth by providing multiple income streams for the client.

generating assets

5.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE  
Education Loan was developed to enable clients conveniently cater for the educational needs of 
their children/dependents without it having a negative impact on their business. Hen ce it is 
exclusively for educational purposes and not business 
The objective of this product is to encourage clients educate their wards while they remain in 
business profitably. 
5.3  TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
Education loan product is targeted at the following category of clients; 
i. Clients who have wards of school age (whether they are already in school or not)  
ii. Clients who are willing to educate their children if they have the needed resources to do so.  
iii. Clients who have wards of school age . The motivation for parents to send their children to 
school is high if they can have access to resources (loan) that they can utilize on their 
children education and payback over time. In this regard, they will not temper with their 
business capital. In addition, repayme nt is easier as they have time to turn their business 
around and repay the loan on installment basis. 
 
5.4   CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
The following criteria shall qualify clients for education loan 
i. Be a registered and active LAPO client. 
ii. New clients are eligible to assess the product 
iii. Education loan can be assessed by an individual client or a group member

7.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE  
LAPO MFB Special loan product was developed to meet the financial needs of existing regular 
loan clients who require higher loans and a monthly repayment schedule. The development of 
this product was necessitated by the fact that after funding r egular loan clients for some time, 
their business activities expand to the point where they require higher loans to sustain their 
business. In the same vein these clients also require monthly loan repayment frequency as it is 
more convenient for them.  
The objective of this loan therefore is to provide higher loans for clients and also give them the 
opportunity to enjoy monthly repayment frequency.  
7.3 TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
LAPO targets the following category of clients; 
i. Existing clients who have fully repaid one loan stage and above. 
ii. Regular clients in need of higher loans to further expand the scope of their business and 
income 
7.4 CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
The following criteria qualify clients for asset loan: 
i. Be a registered and active LAPO client. 
ii. Must have fully repaid one loan stage and above. 
iii. Must have 100% repayment history. 
iv. Must not have any other monthly running loan. 
 
7.5   REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION 
i. Passport photograph - Two recent passport sized photographs will be needed. One will be 
affixed on the loan application form and the other on the client passbook. Subsequent loan 
application requires one passport.

8.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO MFB Agricultural loan products were developed to make funds available to farmers and 
other Agricultural value chain actors at affordable costs. Specifically, the rationale behind th e 
Agricultural product development is to enhance the income of semi urban and rural farmers, 
stimulate and increase the level of financial resources available to Agriculture, improve the 
farming knowledge of the rural farmer exposing them to more mechanized methods of farming, 
and boost Agricultural value chain activities through provision of funds. Nevertheless, this is 
also to improve the social and economic conditions of poor households in a sustainable 
manner. 
 
8.3    TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
LAPO targets the following category of clients; 
i. Existing and practicing crop and animal farmers in the semi urban and rural 
communities. 
ii. Organized viable non-political cooperative societies will be considered for group loans. 
iii. All other Agricultural Value chain actors 
8.4 CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
A prospective beneficiary must be an existing farmer or any of the actors in A gricultural value 
chain who can apply as; 
i. An individual, 
ii. A group comprising of between 5 - 20 members with fund disbursed to individuals 
within the group A viable non -political farmer cooperative society existing in r ural and 
semi-urban communities with genuine Certificate of Registration.

CRITERIA (INDIVIDUAL ANG GROUP CLIENTS) 
 
 INDIVIDUAL LOAN CLIENTS: 
i. Must have been in A gricultural enterprise which may include production, processing,  
input supply and marketing of Agricultural products,

will meet LAPO repayment structure, 
vii. Must not have any other running loan. 
viii. Enterprise must be able to repay the loan.

appraisal must be carried out and approval based on current worth of business.

8.10 POST DISBURSEMENT ACTIVITIES 
The Agricultural Business manager, Agricultural CSO and Branch manager carries out the 
under listed activities after disbursement  
 
• Premium payment to NAIC 
• Submission of ACGSF forms to CBN 
• Interest drawback processing to CBN 
• Treat rebate to clients’ account 
• Notification/claim to NAIC of any insured risk   
• Loan default guarantee claim form submission to CBN 
 
8.11   NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL INSURANCE COOPERATION (NAIC)  
The premium amount to be remitted to NAIC is 90% of the total premium while the 
balance 10% goes to LAPO MFB as other income (commission). NAIC remittance sheet 
captures the following information for each of the clients that were disbursed to for that 
particular month. 
i.  Name of clients,  
ii.  Date of disbursement,  
iii.  Amount disbursed,  
iv. Nature/class of enterprise (different premium rate for different enterprise - 
2.5% for livestock, 2% for arable crop and 1.5% for tree crop),  
v.  Hectares/number of livestock,  
vi. Total premium income for the month,  
vii. Net premium income for the month (gross – 10% commission) and 
xi. Branch manager’s signature. 
 
N.B: NAIC does not cover for bi rd flu and swine fever. Also NAIC only pays 
compensation on the loss experienced by the farmer. Farmers should be informed 
about this during pre -loan training. This means farmers keeps servicing his/her loan 
pending when NAIC compensate to know what balance is left for the client to complete 
his/her payment. 
 
8.11.1 STEPS FOR PREMIUM PAYMENT TO NAIC 
 
 After disbursment, the CSO fills the remittance sheet  
 BM signs and stamps completely filled remittance sheet 
 Where there is an AGBM, the branch does inter-bank transfer of the amount due 
to NAIC for the month to the resident branch of the AGBM where cheque will be

8.13     INTEREST DRAW BACK PROGRAMME (IDP) PROCESSING PROCEDURE 
This is done on a monthly basis for clients who completed their loan repayment as 
agreed in the loan terms without default; as any loan that exceeds the agreed loan 
tenure will not be accepted by CBN.  This is carried out by the AGBM. Where ther e is no 
AGBM the CSO carries out this process. 
 
 Upon full repayment by the clients, the  AGBM or CSO where there is no AGBM  
brings out the filed original certificates of all the clients  
 Data Entry staff  prints report 33 for the clients who have completed their loan 
tenure from Orbit R  
 Report 33 gives detailed information on the loan repayment history of the client 
 The AGBM or CSO where there is no Business manager calculates the interest 
element from the report 33 generated for each of the clients. 
 The AGBM or CSO where there is no AGBM enters the clients’ information into 
the CBN Interest Draw Back programme (IDP) template provided by CBN.  
 The 40% of the actual interest paid on the completed loan is calcula ted and 
remark given by the AGBM/CSO. 
 Upon completion of the IDP form, submission of soft copy is made to the CBN via 
their email address. 
 The AGBM/CSO also prints out the hard copy of the completed IDP form  
 The Internal Control Officer checks the hard copy of the IDP template

 The AGBM /CSO  takes the stamped and signed copy to  Development Finance 
Office in CBN for submission and onward processing by CBN 
 Documents to be attached to the IDP template for submission are;  the original 
ACGSF certificate of the clients, the printed report 33 for each client and a cover

phone call, email, text message or word of mouth during visit to their office. 
 
8.13.1 TREATMENT OF 40% REBATE TO CLIENTS’ ACCOUNT 
a. CBN makes payment into the LAPO MFB  Branch Account that was written in the 
submitted IDP template to CBN. 
b. The AGBM/CSO collects the schedule of payment from CBN  
c. The AGBM/CSO notify the Head of Operations (HOP) about the payment. 
d. The HOP checks to ensure that the payment amount has been received into the 
branch account. Where there is variance in amount paid and that on the 
schedule, CBN is immediately notified by the Business manager and followed up 
until correction is made. 
e. The Business Manager indicates the account number of each client against their 
name on the payment schedule collected from CBN. 
f. The payment schedule on which the clients account numbers have been 
indicated on should be photocopied and submitted to th e Branch Manager (BM) 
or Internal Control Officer (ICO) 
g. The BM/Internal Control Officer checks the document to ensure that the clients’   
account number tallies with the name on the payment schedule.

CLAIM PROCESS 
 
i. The CSO ascertain the genuineness of the claim by the client  
ii. The CSO request for the date the natural disaster or the disease outbreak 
occurred  
iii. The CSO informs the AGBM through phone call imm ediately and the AGBM in -
turn informs National Agricultural Insurance Cooperation (NAIC) in his/her state 
immediately 
iv. The CSO request for photograph of the flooded farm area or dead animals. 
v. In the case of disease outbreak on livestock farm, the CSO reques t for veterinary 
doctor’s report from the farmer. 
vi. The CSO collates the documents (photographs, veterinary doctors report, farm 
records) from the clients  
vii. The CSO fills the claims form for the clients using the given information  
viii. The CSO attaches the documents collected from the client to the Claim form and 
send to the AGBM 
ix. The AGBM writes letter of notification/claim to NAIC office in the State of 
occurrence using the information on the claim form.  The content of the letter 
should include:  
i. Name and Phone number of the client. 
ii. Date insured. 
iii. Amount of the loan insured. 
iv. Farmer’s farm address. 
v. Description of incident and level of damage (Hectare, plot, number/age of 
animal, etc.) 
vi. Branch account number in which the indemnity should be paid 
Attach the following to the letter: 
i. Farm records  
ii. Photocopy of loan NAIC certificate  
iii. Photocopy of NAIC remittance sheet (mark the name of the client in the sheet) 
iv. Photograph of the farm area that had issues such as flood, fire, pest, etc ., (in the 
case of crop production).  
v. Photograph of the dead livestock (in the case of livestock farm). 
vi. Veterinary doctor’s report from the farmer (in the case of livestock farm).

8.17 REPAYMENT   METHODOLOGY   
     
8.17.1 AGRICULTURAL CROP, LIVESTOCK AND AGRO PROCESSORS/ MARKETERS LOAN: 
 
Group loans : The first installment is expected to be paid 30, 60 or 90 days after 
disbursement based on the agricultural enterprise. This is to allow the borrower invest 
the loan and generate inflows to be able to repay. Even though the product is a 
monthly loan, all repayments will be made in monthly group meetings. CSO 
responsibility is to collect both elements of savings and loan installments, record the 
transaction in field collection sheet and same in the clients’ passbook. 
 
Individual loan :  Client pays directly into LAPO MfB account and presents teller to 
branch office. The first installment is expected to be paid 30, 60 or 90 days after 
disbursement based on the agricultural enterprise  so that the borrower  can invest the 
loan and generate inflows to be able to repay. CSO responsibility is to record the 
transaction in client’s passbook and the individual union field collection sheet. 
 
Agricultural Cooperative Loan  
The first installment is expected to be paid 4 months after loan disbursement so that 
the borrower has time to invest the loan and generate profit to be able to repay.   
3.   Input financing 
Repayment shall be ONE -OFF after an agreed g race per iod depending on the MOA  
signed with the association/group. CSO responsibility is to collect both elements of 
savings and loan installments during monthly union meetings, record the transaction in 
field collection sheet and client passbook. During grace pe riod, clients are encouraged

8.18   MONITORING 
i. The first monitoring officer to this loan is the CSO. Branch  credit committee also 
provides second level monitoring. 
ii. In view of the above, both the CSO and branch credit committee members are 
expected to visit the client within 14 days after loan disbursement to ensure loan 
was invested in the business and not diverted. 
iii. ABGM and Area supervisors are to ensure that all disbursement procedures are 
adhered to using the Agricultural checklist (see annexure below),  
iv. Zonal and Head Office team will provide additional monitoring. 
   
8.19 CLIENT DUTIES 
i. Promptly submit all necessary documents required for loan processing 
ii. Submit duly completed LAPO MFB loan application form  
iii. Provide one or two external guarantors to guarantee the loan based on loan size 
iv. Obey all rules and regulations of the organization and that of the union. 
v. Attend monthly meetings of the group on time. Lateness and absenteeism should 
be discouraged. 
vi. Make repayment without defaulting. 
vii. Make proper use of credit facility without diverting the loan 
viii. Resist the temptation to take multiple loans. 
ix. Take responsibility for fellow union member repayment in the event of default

ADJUSTMENT MADE TO LOAN TERMS AND CONDITIONS 
Loan Obligor limit: 
All individual loans obligor limit is increased from N3, 000,000 to maximum of N5, 000,000.  
However, the maximum initial loan size for all individual loan products remains at One Million naira 
(N1,000,000) with one suitable guarantor to substitute as a collateral 
Subsequent incremental loan amount for all individual loan products shall be based on the repayment 
capacity of the customers after due business analysis and verification. 
All repeat loan customers can however assess any amount based on the repayment capacity. 
All individual clients in unions who are not willing to assess loans under the union guaranty, with good 
business and repayment capacity can be allowed individual loan disbursement in the groups.  
However, for Group loans, total amount to be disbursed at any given point in time must not be more than 
one million naira (N1, 000,000). Putting together the various loan product assessed by the customer 
For loan security purpose, all customers assessing  loan amount below N2,000,000, will provide one 
suitable, willing and capable guarantor while loan amount above N2,000,000 will provide two suitable, 
willing and capable guarantors due to the trust and relationship built over the years with the bank by the  
customers. 
Guarantors for Loans above two million naira (N2, 000,000) will present one undated cheque each as extra 
guaranty for loan disbursed while loans below two million naira (N2, 000,000) can be disbursed with one 
guarantor without undated cheque. 
GROUP LOAN -: NITIAL LOAN SIZE: ₦30,000 - ₦150,000 -: initial loan size for Group Loans has been increase up to 
One Hundred and Fifty Thousand Naira. (N150,000) 
Subsequent incremental loan amount shall be based on the repayment capacity of the customers aft er due business 
analysis and verification. 
All repeat loan customers can however assess any amount based on the repayment capacity. 
SME: Obligor limit increased to 3, 000,000 to be determined by 33.3% of net pay. Above N2m will require an 
approval from SME GH/BH. 
Below 100,000 – 1,000,000 ---- 1 guarantor, Above 1,000,000----------2 guarantors

PROCESS FLOW ON COLLATERAL VALUATION For SME LOANS 
Clients willing to access loans from Five Million Naira (₦5million) and above must have their pledge assets valuated. 
This could be Vehicles, Machinery or Landed properties. 
Clients are to avail any of the following documents stated below. 
 Certificate of Occupancy  
 Deed of Assignment 
 Survey Plan 
 Deed of Conveyance 
 Deed of Transfer 
 Deed of Gift 
With any of this document available, the team is expected to attach and fill the request form and send it to the 
platform team who then send an estate surveyor covering various locations. 
The report is sent within 72hrs. 
Amount Charged: – The charge on collateral valuation ranges from N50, 000 down to N10, 000 depending on the 
loan amount which the customer is assessing and the type of collateral for valuation.

9.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO MfB -Small Business Loan (SBL) product was developed to meet the needs of two classes 
of economically active persons 
i. Small and Medium Scale business persons who could not assess loans from our regular 
branches as a result of the size of their business, which needed more funds than our regular 
branches could provide. 
ii. Prospects that were interested in assessing loan from LAPO MfB, but did not want to do so 
through groups because they are too busy to attend union meetings. 
 
9.3 TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
LAPO MfB Small Business Loan targets the following category of clients; 
i. Economically active persons in business 
ii. Small and Medium enterprise owners who needed more funds than what they can assess 
through the regular loan product 
iii. Regular loan clients in need of higher loans to further expand the scope of their business 
and income 
 
9.4 BUSINESSES TO BE FUNDED 
i. Trade businesses with regular cash flow and all forms of legality 
ii. Service renderers with additional large scale trading business and regular cash flow. 
iii. Registered schools with government approval , with at least nursery and primary sessions 
and conducting external exams. 
iv. Government certified Hospitals belonging to the person applying for the loan. A dispensary 
might be an added advantage 
v. All businesses on the LAPO MfB exclusion list are not eligible

9.5 CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
The following criteria qualify clients for SBL product; 
i. Client must have been in business for at least one year.  
ii. Client must have a verifiable  business either in lock up shops, open shops, caravans, homes 
or any good selling shop that is sited in good location for the purpose of patronage from 
customers. 
iii. The business must be in a very good location for the purpose of patronage. 
iv. Start-ups are not qualified  
v. Business owner s must be able to prove  the ownership of the business by providing the 
business/site receipts and other relevant business documents, which MUST be in the name 
of the person applying for the loan, to authenticate their ownership 
vi. Must be able to provide one  suitable guarantor for loans below N1,000, 000 and 2 suitable 
guarantors for loans above N1,000,000 without undated cheque 
vii. Should be aged between 25 and 75 years. 
viii. Service providers are not qualified unless they also engage in trading activities. 
ix. Mobile traders are not qualified except they are landlords / landladies or those living or 
staying in a family house and can be verified for security  
x. Migrating trader are not allowed except those who can be apprised in their homes and in 
the markets where they sell on a particular market day. 
xi. Suppliers must be land lords or landladies 
xii. Clients selling fairly used cloths must have verifiable packing store and must have been in 
the business for at least two years. Retailers are not qualified. 
xiii. Wood c onvertors must have been in business for at least two years, the sawmill owner 
must be able to attest and guaranty that the person is operating in the mill with a proof by 
becoming one of the guarantors. 
xiv. Butchers must be members of their association,  who have turns for killing cows and the 
chairman of the slaughter house must be involved. However, if it is a personal abattoir, it 
must be licensed. 
xv. For Restaurant and bar, the location must be viable, the quality of food must be good and 
the quantity cooked daily should be worth up to N50, 000 at least. The person must also be 
involved in the sales of drinks. 
xvi. For tailors, the person must be sellin g tailoring accessories or o ther items. Have at least 
three machines and workers or apprentices working with him/her. 
xvii. Services (Rentals), must have already owned some number of chai rs and tables  as well as 
the location of the business. How often they render their services, i.e. daily, weekly, 
fortnightly or monthly. 
xviii. Proprietor of a school, who is interested in th e loan product, must meet the following 
conditions before they can participate. 
a. School must be registered and government approved

b. Must be in their permanent site.  
xxiv. For hospitals, they must be owners of the hospital, which must be government approved,

9.6   GUARANTORS ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA   
 
i. Guarantors must have enough repayment capacity to repay the loan in case of default. 
ii. Guarantors must be willing to repay the loan. 
iii. Guarantors must present at least one (1) undated cheque leaflet as a security (where 
applicable) 
iv. Business guarantors must have been in business for at least one year.  
v. Guarantors should either be working or doing busin ess and preferably one family member 
and one family friend and should be willing and have capacity to repay the loan in the event 
of any default.  
vi. Situations where the business is jointly owned (as in the case of joint proprietorship) or 
jointly managed (as in the case of spouses) three guarantors will be required. 
vii. Situations where the spouse is not economically active, three guarantors will be required as 
the spouse will be the third guarantor to the loan. 
viii. Situations where the spouse is working or engaged in a business that is not jointly owned 
and verified to be separate from the business being used for loan assessment, two 
guarantors can be accepted.   
ix. Guarantors must be aged between 25 and 60 years

iv. Client passbook- Disbursed loan should be written in the client’s passbook as soon as it is 
disbursed. Passbook should also be filled and signed by the CSO or manager whenever any

 9.9. OPERATIONAL METHODOLOGY 
 
i. Timeline for loan disbursem ent to a new client is maximum two  weeks after every

carried out and approval based on current worth of business

9.10    LOAN CLASSIFICATION 
SBL loan can be classified into three: 
i. CLASS 1: This refers to SBL loans between N100, 000 and  N500, 000. This class of loans can 
be accessed by new clients and existing clients of other LAPO MFB products.  
ii. CLASS 2 : This refers to SB L loans between N501, 000 to N1, 000 , 000 . This can only be 
accessed by former class 1 clients  who have accessed loan  at least once  with 100% 
repayment history and repayment capacity to repay the loan.  
 
iii. CLASS 3 : This ref ers to SBL loans a bove N1, 000 , 000 to N3, 000,000 . This can only be 
accessed by former class 2 clients who have assessed loan of N500, 000  and above  with 
good repayment history and with repayment capacity to repay the loan. This class of loans 
must be approved by the zonal manager.

9.12    LOAN APPROVAL PROCEDURE 
i. The client is to submit a hand written/ typed and duly signed application letter indicating 
his/her interest for the loan before completing the loan application form. 
ii. BM and CSO must verify to confirm that client is the actual owner of the business. 
iii. Loan appraisal to be carried out by the CSO using cash flow based lending methodology. 
iv. Verification to be carried out by credit committee members on client’s home and business. 
v. Home and business of at least one guarantor MUST be verified by Credit Committee 
members before approval. (for loans of N300, 000 and above) 
vi. Credit committee members are; MBM, ABM, Accountant and Compliance Officer

9.13   PROCEEDURE FOR APPROVING ABOVE ₦1,000,000 
xii. CSO conducts appraisal and recommends to credit committee.  
xiii. Credit committee conducts verification, reviews the recommendation, certify and send to 
the Area Manager for approval for all loans above N1,000,000 – N2,000,00 in the respective 
Areas.  
xiv. The Area Manager gives final approval after a careful review of the application and 
communicates approval back to the branch immediately it is received. 
xv. While all loans above N2,000,000 – N5,000,000 is send to the Zonal Manager for approval 
after due appraisal and verification by both the Branch Credit Committee and Area Manager  
xvi. The Zonal Manager gives final approval after a careful review of the application and 
communicates approval back to the branch immediately it is received. 
xvii. Every exceptional case above N5, 000,000 is sent to head office for approval. 
xviii. Every exceptional case above the loan obligor limit of N5,000,000 must be appraise 
using the SME loan appraisal methodology.  
xix. While the necessary loan documentation for SME loan customers is obtain from  the client 
and kept in customer loan file for record purpose. OR 
xx. On the other hand, such exceptional case above the loan obligor limit should be transfer to 
the SME business unit for proper classification of the loan product. 
 
 
9.14. DISBURSEMENT METHODOLOGY 
i. Disbursement will be carried out in the branch office by credit committee members. 
ii. Client is to come with both guarantors on the day of disbursement. However, where both 
guarantors cannot come at the same time, the Manager can attend to them as they come. 
iii. Manager interviews the guarantors and also enlightens them on the terms and conditions 
of the loan as well as their responsibilities as guarantors. 
iv. The compliance officer must certify that all documentations are perfected and also that the 
client has savings balance commensurate with the approved loan amount. 
v. CIM also certifies that credit bureau and cross referencing has been conducted on the 
client. 
vi. In cases of re -application, CIM ensures that all outstanding loan balance has been fully 
repaid before new loan disbursement 
vii. Disbursement should be entered in the client’s passbook as soon as it is disbursed.

viii. Loan amount is disbursed into client’s savings account with LAPO MFB. Before direct 
transfer into client’s corresponding bank account bearing the same  name on the loan 
contract agreement form already endorsed by the client. 
ix. However, where the customer does not have a commercial bank account for the purpose of 
transfer, cheque can be issue for payment of such disbursement. 
x. A copy of the loan agreement form and repayment schedule to be given to ALL clients at the

xi. Loans CANNOT be disbursed to two persons from the same household. 
xii. Loans CANNOT be disbursed to guarantors and they cannot guarantee for more than one 
person, hence the need for credit bureau and cross referencing. 
xiii. Loans that have not been subjected to credit bureau and cross referencing CANNOT be 
disbursed. 
9.15 REPAYMENT METHODOLOGY          
i.    All loan repayment must come on the stipulated date under all circumstances. 
ii. Mode of repayment is monthly. 
iii. Repayment should be made into the branch’s bank account and teller presented to the CSO 
on or before the scheduled repayment date. 
iv. Staffs are prohibited from handling cash, therefore clients are to pay directly to the branch 
account number given to them and teller submitted thereafter to CSO or any staff in the 
office and ensures that the passbook is updated. 
v. On no account should any staff give their personal bank account number to clients for the 
purpose of repayment or any official transaction. 
vi. Clients should be advised to always come to the office with their passbook whenever they 
are coming to make payments or any other financial transaction. 
vii. CSO should ensure that repayments and all financial transactions are entered in the cli ent’s 
passbook immediately such transaction occurs and also signed for clear record purpose. 
viii. Any loan repayment that is paid after the accountant has balance th e day’s transaction 
should be boxed for the next day’s transaction. 
 
9.16 MONITORING 
 
i. The first monitoring officer to the loan is the CSO 
ii. CSOs and BMs MUST visit client business immediately after disbursement to ensure loan is 
not diverted. 
iii. Clients should be called at least a week and a day before their repayment date to remind 
them of their obligation to repay the loan. 
iv. Branch to be monitored by CIM, State AMs, Zonal office as well as Head office.

i. Promptly submit all necessary documents required for loan processing

 9.18    RECORD KEEPING SYSTEM IN A MEGA BRANCH  
 
i. All records are to be kept by the branch accountant; the branch is to maintain one data 
base for small business loan, regular and other related loan products in the branch. 
ii. The assistant branch manager disburses all loan products under the supervision and guide 
of the Mega Branch Manager (MBM) 
iii. The assistant manager collects and balances the transactions for regular CSOs on a da ily 
basis before submitting to DES and accountant for posting.  
iv. SBL clients pay directly to the branch  correspondent account and submit tellers  at the 
branch. DES  to posts all tellers and gives all tellers to the branch accountant in order to 
enable them update the branch records. 
v.  A safe is purchased and kept under the custody of the branch accountant in cases of late 
payment by the clients i.e. for non-banking services branches. 
vi. The accountant and the MIS data entry staff produces branch reports and submi t on a 
weekly and monthly basis respectively as required.

10.2    PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO Microfinance Bank Limited set goal is to c ontinually impact the economy socially and 
economically with tailored financial products while retaining the position as number one 
Microfinance institution in Nigeria
