The bank has over the years been able to carve a significant niche by evolving from dis bursing 
soft loans as low as N100 to high loan of N2m in line with various economic realities. 
Achievement on this strategic approach has so far been enormous with the increasing crave for 
modifications to reflect changing realities in our economy occasion ed by various governmental 
policy in the bid to diversify the economy. 
Currently, a significant number of the entrepreneurs are consistently upscaling from the micro 
end to small and medium end; and from medium to large enterprise not discounting it 
attendant financial implication and difficulty in accessing finance given the risk acceptance 
criteria set by commercial and developmental banks   
As an institution, majority of this clients that falls within this emerging segment called the 
“mixing middle’’ hav e repeatedly cycled out on the limited offerings and are consistently 
yearning for a bigger facility sum in line with their expansion drive leaving a lots of them to sort 
or move to competition. 
For the bank to continually retain and maximize the increasin g and economically active 
segment while deepening our position, the Small medium enterprise space is being broadened 
to accommodate more businesses, sectors and economically viable locations with adeq uate 
and acceptable cash flow.  
 
10.3   TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
 
LAPO MFB Small and Medium Enterprise Loan target the following category of clients: 
Registered or Unregistered economically active persons or businesses with adequate and 
acceptable cash flow who need as much as N50, 000,000 to expand their business activities. 
 
 
10.4   BUSINESS TO BE FUNDED 
 
Trading businesses with regular and adequate cash flow not limited to the following;  
i. Building Materials, spare parts, electronics, Boutiques,  
ii. Educational Services such as Schools, Vocational/ skill acquisition Centers and Bookshops. 
iii. Health and Medical Services. (Hospitals, Pharmacies, Laboratories) 
iv. Agricultural value Chain. Fish feeds, chicken feeds, processors of agricultural products 
mainly for local consumption, bakery, and confectionaries.  
v. Professional Services. Medium and Large Laundry Business,  
vi. Cooking gas retailers and accessories dealers

10.5   GENERAL ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
 
10.5.1 New Clients- Client with no previous credit history with LAPO MFB 
i. Business experience: Minimum of 2years’ experience (present business activity and       
location) 
ii. Credit experience: Not a necessity. 
iii. Documents: Bank acceptable ID, proof of business tran saction/business records, rent 
receipts for at least 6month or Lease document/Agreement 
 
10.5.2  Existing Clients-Clients of SBL, SUFEN, and any of the bank’s other products 
i. Business experience: Minimum of 2years’ experience  
ii. Present business activity and location 
iii. Credit experience: Previous LAPO MFB loans between N700, 000 and N1, 000, 000. 
iv. Documents:        Rent receipt for 6months or lease rent, business record can be waived for 
loan amount up to N1,000,000 satisfactory business relationship with LAPO 
 
10.6   CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
i. Adults of not less than 25years old but not more than 75years old. 
ii. The client business premises must be in a permitted location (main shift structure, mobile 
business not allowed. 
iii. The business must be in a very good location for the purpose of patronage. 
iv. Potential clients must have been in that particular line of business for a minimum period of 
one year (12months) and have proven knowledge and training in business 
v. Start-ups or those intending to change their line of business are not qualified. 
vi. Client’s business must be registered and have transaction records. However, clients whose 
business are not registered and have no transaction records cannot access above N1million. 
vii. Business owners must be able to prove the ownership o f the business by providing 
business/ site receipts and all other relevant documents, which MUST be in the name of the 
person applying for the loan, to authenticate their ownership 
viii. Satisfactory Credit search from at least two of the credit bureau

10.10ACCEPTABLE COLLATERAL 
i. Inventory: This should be worth 200% of the loan amount  
ii. Perishable goods are not allowed 
iii. Fixed /Term Deposit in LAPO MFB 
  (a)  The account will be lien 
       (b)  Fixed deposit can be combined with other collateral to achieve total collateral coverage  
of 130% of loan amount. 
  (c)  Other banks’ Fixed Term Deposits are not acceptable as collateral.  
   iv. Vehicles:  Vehicles may be used as collateral only if the Credit administrators have   sighted 
it and agreed on a liquidation value to be added in the Security Agreement  
 Vehicle must be highly marketable but subject to credit appraisal 
 Vehicle must be comprehensively insured with LAPO noted as first loss payee 
 For vehicle with comprehensive insurance policy, client shall endorse LAPO as first loss 
payee on insurance policy which will be consummated by insurance company. 
v.  Machinery: Age analysis must be adopted with comprehensive insurance noting LAPO as 
not first loss payee 
vi. Legal Mortgage: 
(a) The bank’s legal team must carry out a search on the property to ascertain     
ownership and encumbrance status 
(b) The property must be valued by the bank’s approved estate valuer  
(c) Cost of land search and valuation charges are to be borne by the client. 
(d) The title of document must be registered. 
vii. In the event of a collateral contribution by clients and guarantors, at least 50 % of the 
total collateral must belong to the client. (This implies that client and guarantor can be 
share on loan; in case of default by client, guarantor might not take payment seriously 
on the ground that their collateral is already with the bank)

i. Where a business is owned by more than one person (partnership or limited liability), 
owners/shareholders represe nting at least 66% of the share capital must be either the 
principal borrower or guarantor(s) of the loan. Persons who (can) exert significant influence

10.11.2 THIRD PARTY COLLATERAL PROVIDERS 
This refers to natural persons or corporate bodies other than the principal borrower of the loan 
who is pledging his property on behalf of the borrower. 
i. The Credit Administrators may accept collateral pledge by a third party subject to 
satisfactory appraisal of mortgagor 
ii. Third party collateral providers shall be mandated to undertake a third party collateral 
agreement 
iii. A third party collateral provider can either be a natural person or corporate body. 
iv.A third party collateral provider can also be a guarantor  
v. Personal guarantee of promoter shall be a pre-condition for disbursement. 
 
10.11.3 MORAL GUARANTORS  
i.  This should be someone that can exert some level of influence on the client to ensure 
repayment. This could be a spouse, relative or friend etc. 
ii.  This is an additional source to the loan security

10.12   LOAN ASSESSMENT REQUIREMENTS  
i. The Investment plan/loan purpose must be clearly stated on the application form, loan 
proposal memorandum and clearly understood by the Relationship Manager and credit 
administrators 
ii.  In case of a specific purchase and/ or international purchase, an exact breakdown of the 
investment plan is mandatory. Details of the location, supplier(s), shipping and 
payment methods are necessary. Evidences available should be added to the credit file 
iii.  For the purpose of KYC and collateral collection, RM must conduct Business and 
household visits for the Client (or the principal owner in case of corporate entities). The 
Officer must complete and SIGN the “Confirmation of Address” form  to confirm that 
due diligence was conducted on the client’s residence. Availability of rent receipt does 
not negate the necessity of the Confirmation of Address form. 
iv.  RM to visit guarantor’s Business and Residential premises, this should be validated by  
v. CREDIT ADMINISTRATORS. 
vi.  All collateral for SME loans must be sighted. Pictures must be taken and filed. 
vii.  The RM shall gather information for the profit and loss statement of the Client for a 
period of no less than 12 months. Clients who cannot provide sales records for at least 
12 months are not eligible for amounts higher than one Million Naira. All sales books 
and invoices used in the cash flow assessment must be thoroughly verified by CREDIT 
ADMINISTRATORS during verification. 
viii. All assets considered in the “Balance Sheet” must be verified/ confirmed. If it is not 
possible to verify the asset value, it should be included as a comment in the Balance 
sheet. Any fixed asset considered must be sighted by the RM. Where it is not available 
for sighting, it should be clearly stated in the appraisal memorandum  
ix. Bank statement for a 12month period is required for account used by the client. 
Where   the client has multiple accounts, bank statements for at least 6months from 
each account    is required. 
x. Loan Proposal Mem orandum is sent electronically to Credit Administrator is the first 
Analyst  
xi.  Thorough verification should be conducted by CREDIT ADMINISTRATORS doing 
appraisal 
xii.  Terms and conditions of the loan should be well communicated, should a guarantor 
decide not to  sign the guarantor’s agreement, the CREDIT ADMINISTRATORS must 
communicate the client for a replacement, the replacement should be subjected to a 
fresh appraisal. 
xiii.  Debt Service Ratio (DS R): The ratio of installment to Repayment Capacity must be > 
1.40.  
xiv. Credit Administrator make recommendation and forward via mail to for final Approval

10.17    LOAN REPAYMENT METHODOLGY

a   follow up from the RM and Credit Administrator

submitted to the Branch accountant.

due date are to either make direct  transfer or cash lodgment into to branch 
correspondent account with evidence of payment to the RM

purpose of repayment or any official transaction.

any transaction.

10.18   LOAN MONITORING 
i. The first monitoring officer to the loan is the RM and Branch Managers. 
ii. Credit Administrator major role is to ensure quality of loan in addition to driving 
businesses for actualization of set target. 
iii. RM MUST visit client’s business within one week of disbursement to ensure loan is not 
diverted and subsequently, once in e very month with visit status update submitted to 
the credit administrator. This report shall form part of their monthly report to the Head 
office. 
iv. For asset finance Loans, vendor must be confirmed by the Loan officer/Credit 
Administrator. Authority to pay must be issued by the client for either a Bank draft or 
direct disbursement in favor of the vendor.  This is to curb possible diversion of loan 
proceeds. 
v. The asset shall be purchased in LAPO name with a comprehensive insurance noting 
LAPO as first loss payee. 
vi. Original document must be vaulted in with a transfer authority to operate letter in 
addition to photocopy to client.   
vii. Clients must be notified at least one week before their repayment due date. A reminder 
call must be made one day before the repayment  date to remind them of their 
obligation to repay the loan. 
viii. Credit administrators are to within the first month of disbursement visit client. 
Subsequent visits can be periodic which shall also form part of their monthly report to 
Head Office. 
10.19   CLIENT DUTIES 
i. Provide all required documents as requested for informed credit decision  
ii. Submit duly completed LAPO MFB loan application form  
iii. Provide suitable guarantors to guarantee the loan 
iv. Provide collateral as may be required for the  loan 
v. Make good the fac ility in line with terms and condition as specified in the offer letter 
and loan agreement 
vi. Fund his or her account with initial cash deposit as requested and stated in the offer 
letter 
vii. Ensure his or her account is adequately funded to meet repayment as they fall due 
viii. Fund his or her account with all cost that might arise in the course of loan process.

10.20   LOAN LIQUIDATION, INTEREST WAIVER AND TOP-UP PROCEDURE 
i. Clients are allowed to liquidate their loan anytime at no additional cost. 
ii. Interest will not be waived for those that pay their loan rental in advance. 
iii. Interest will be paid on any loan that enters into the next month with just one day. 
iv. For clients who desire bigger loan amount or top –up, a reappraisal of current facility 
performance and possible capacity for amount requested will be carried out. 
v. Existing facil ity which  will be liquidated into the new loan amount with the 
difference made available for client to draw. 
vi. Any client intending to pay off must notify the Relationship Manager in written who 
must advice the client of his or her outstanding. The client must settle on the advices 
balance within 10days of notification. 
vii. Should clients not settle within the month of advice, client must pay the interest for 
the new month. 
viii. Every of the above must be approved by the SME-CONSMUER Credit Team Lead. 
ix. The Branch Manager, Accountant and ICO must ensure clients account or branch 
correspondent bank account is adequately funded. Compliance officer MUST certify 
this transaction before it is carried out. 
x. PLEASE NOTE THAT EVERY ELIGIBLE CLIENT IS ENTITLED TO ONLY ONE LOAN TOP-UP.

11.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO MfB – Development Bank of Nigeria Business Support Loan  (DBNBS) was developed to 
reward client loyalty as it is a cheaper source of fund.  DBNBS is financed with funds from 
Development Bank of Nigeria (DBN) . The objective of this fund is to finance businesses of 
entrepreneurs who require funds to expand their business activities , while LAPO MfB is poised 
at providing c heap funds for her esteemed clients to reward clients’  loyalty over the years. 
DBNBS product is therefore developed to meet this need.  
11.3 TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
The primary targets of the product are  Regular, SBL and SME  clients with good r epayment 
history. Regular client that has viable business with repayment capacity and good credit history, 
SBL clients who have assessed SBL loan at least twice without any incidence of default and SME 
clients who have completed one loan cycle without any incidence o f default. Trade businesses 
with regular cash flow and all forms of legality, Manufacturing and Production Firms

11.4 BUSINESSES TO BE FUNDED 
 
i. Trade businesses with regular cash flow and all forms of legality 
ii. Manufacturing  
iii. Production 
 
11.5 CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
The following criteria qualify clients for DBNBS product: 
i. Existing SBL clients who have assessed loans at least twice 
ii. Existing SME clients who have completed at least one loan circle. 
iii. These clients must also meet the eligibility criteria for SBL and SME 
iv. Regular client that has viable business with repayment capacity and good credit history. 
 
11.6 GUARANTORS ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA  
 
i. Guarantors must have enough repayment capacity to repay the loan in case of default. 
ii. Guarantors must be willing to repay the loan. 
iii. Guarantors must present one (1) undated cheque leaflet each as security for the loan on   
the day of disbursement (for loans of N1, 000, 000-N2, 000,000). 
iv. Business guarantors must have been in business for at least one year.  
v. At least two out of the three parties to the loan should be married, i.e. either the client 
and one guarantor or the two guarantors, (where the client is not married) MUST be 
married. 
vi. Guarantors should either be working or doing business and preferably one family 
member and one family friend and should be willing and have capacity to repay the loan 
in the event of any default.  
vii. Situations where the business is jointly owned (as in the case of joint proprietorship) or     
jointly managed (as in the case of spouses) three guarantors will be required. 
viii. Situations where the spouse is not economically active, three guarantors will be required 
as the spouse will be the third guarantor to the loan. 
ix. Situations where the spouse is working or engaged in a business that is not joint ly owned  
and verified to be separate from the business being used for loan assessment, two 
guarantors can be accepted.   
x. Guarantors must be aged between 25 and 60 years.

11.9   OPERATIONAL METHODOLOGY 
i. On no account should DBNBS be disbursed to clients with other running loans.  
ii. All loans must be fully repaid before a new loan can be disbursed. 
iii. Every loan stage is treated as a fresh loan and as such in -depth business appraisal must 
be carried out and approval based on current worth of business. 
iv. Credit committee MUST verify both house and business of client  
v. Credit committee to also visit house and business of at least one guarantor  for loans of 
N300, 000 and above. 
 
11.10 PROCEDURE FOR PERFECTING DEED OF HYPOTHECATION 
i. The format is printed out from the system and any of the credit committee members 
takes the document to the client’s business place to complete the ‘Description of the 
Hypothecated goods’ during verification. 
ii. Goods to be listed in the deed of hypothecation shall include both current and fixed 
assets relating to the business. 
iii. This document is reviewed with the client so that he/she understands the content and 
implication of the document. 
iv. This do cument MUST be reviewed with the client and guarantors on the day of 
disbursement before all parties sign. 
v. The witnesses for the borrower shall be the two guarantors to the loan. 
vi. On NO ACCOUNT should this document be filed in the client’s file without fill ing and 
listing the hypothecated goods and assets  
vii. Stock and assets documented in the deed of hypothecation as collateral for loan should 
not be less than 150% of approved loan amount

i. Client’s address. 
ii. Date of application 
iii. LAPO office address 
iv. Title of the letter 
v. Loan amount 
vi. Loan duration 
vii. Intended repayment amount 
viii. Name of client 
ix. Signature of client

11.12 LOAN APPROVAL PROCEDURE 
i. The client is to submit a hand written/ typed and duly signed application letter 
indicating his/her interest for the loan before completing the loan application form. 
ii. BM and CSO must verify to confirm that client is the actual owner of the business. 
iii. Loan appraisal to be carried out by the CSO using cash flow based lending methodology. 
iv. Verification to be carried out by credit committee members on clients home and 
business. 
v. Home and business of at least one guarantor MUST be verified by Credit Committee 
members before approval. 
vi. Credit committee members shall be MBM, ABM, Accountant and Compliance Officer  
vii. Whoever carries out verification MUST complete and sign the credit committee 
verification form. 
11.13 DISBURSEMENT METHODOLOGY 
i. Disbursement will be carried out in the branch office immediately after loan approval 
ii. Client is to come with both guarantors on the day of disbursement. However, where 
both guarantors cannot come at the same time, the Manager can attend to them as 
they come. 
iii. Manager interviews the guarantors an d also enlightens them on the terms and 
conditions of the loan as well as their responsibilities as guarantors. 
iv. The compliance officer must certify that all documentations are perfected and also 
that the client has savings balance commensurate with the approved loan amount. 
v. Compliance officer to also certify that client has fully repaid all outstanding loan(s) 
vi. Disbursement should be entered in the client’s passbook as soon as it is disbursed. 
vii. The branch manager disburses the loan in regular branches, while the credit 
committee     disburses in mega branches. 
viii. Loan amount is disbursed into client’s savings account with LAPO MFB. Before direct 
transfer into client’s corresponding bank account bearing the same name on the loan 
contract agreement form already endorsed by the client. 
ix. However, where the customer does not have a commercial bank account for the 
purpose of transfer, cheque can be issue for payment of such disbursement. 
x. A copy of the loan agreement form and repayment schedule to be given to ALL clients 
at the point of disbursement 
xi. Loans CANNOT be disbursed to two persons from the same household. 
xii. Loans CANNOT be disbursed to guarantors and they cannot guarantee for more than 
one person, hence the need for credit bureau and cross referencing. 
xiii. Loans that ha ve not been subjected to credit bureau and cross referencing CANNOT 
be disbursed.

xiv. On NO ACCOUNT should any other loan be disbursed to the client after DBN

11.14 REPAYMENT   METHODOLOGY          
i. All loan repayment must come on the stipulated date under all circumstances. 
ii. Mode of repayment is monthly. Client is expected to repay the first repayment 
installment 30 days after loan disbursement. 
iii. Repayment should be made into the branch’s bank account and teller presented to 
the CSO on or before the scheduled repayment date. 
iv. Staff are prohibited from handling cash, therefore clients are to pay directly to the 
branch account number given to them and teller submitted thereafter to CSO or any 
staff in the office and ensures that the passbook is updated. 
v. On no account should any staff give their personal bank account number to clients for 
the purpose of repayment or any official transaction. 
vi. Clients should be advised to always come to the office with their passbook whenever     
they are coming to make payments or any other financial transaction. 
vii. CSO should ensure that repayments and all financial transactions are entered in the   
client’s passbook immediately such transaction occurs and also signed for clear 
record purpose. 
viii. Any loan repayment that is paid after 4pm should be boxed for the next day’s 
transaction. 
 
11.15 MONITORING 
i. The first monitoring officer to the loan is the CSO 
ii. CSOs and BMs MUST visit client business immediately after disbursement to ensure loan 
is not diverted. 
iii. Clients should be called at least a week and a day before their repayment date to 
remind them of their obligation to repay the loan. 
iv. Branch to be monitored by inspectors, state AMs, zonal office as well as head office. 
v. BM and CSOs MUST visit the client at least three (3) days afte r disbursement to ensure 
loan was not diverted, using the loan utilization form. A book is also maintained for this 
purpose. (SBL visitation note)  
vi. Format for keeping this book is S/N, name of staff, date of visit, time of visit, client’s 
name, date of disbursement, shop address, observation, action taken/r ecommendation, 
staff signature.

viii. However, where the customer does not have a commercial bank account for the 
purpose of transfer, cheque can be issue for payment of such disbursement. 
ix. A copy of the loan agreement form and r epayment schedule to be given to ALL 
clients at the point of disbursement. 
x. Loans CANNOT be disbursed to two persons from the same household. 
xi. Loans CANNOT be disbursed to guarantors and they cannot guarantee for more than 
one person, hence the need for credit bureau and cross referencing. 
xii. Loans that have not been subjected to credit bureau and cross referencing CANNOT 
be disbursed. 
xiii. On NO ACCOUNT should any other loan be disbursed to the client after BSL 
disbursement 
 
12.13 REPAYMENT   METHODOLOGY          
i. All loan repayment must come on the stipulated date under all circumstances. 
ii. Mode of repayment is monthly. Client is expected to repay the first repayment 
installment 30 days after loan disbursement. 
iii. Repayment should be made into the branch’s bank account an d teller presented to 
the CSO on or before the scheduled repayment date. 
iv. Staff are prohibited from handling cash, therefore clients are to pay directly to the 
branch account number given to them and teller submitted thereafter to CSO or any 
staff in the office and ensures that the passbook is updated. 
v. On no account should any staff give their personal bank account number to clients 
for the purpose of repayment or any official transaction.

13.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO MfB -Supporting Female Entrepreneurs loan (SUFEN) was developed to meet the 
funding need s of economically active female entrepreneurs who wish to expand the 
scope of their business activities. The desire to have a dedicated loan for women is what 
necessitated the development of this product. Hence the loan is gender sensitive.  
13.3 TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
LAPO MfB SUFEN loan is targeted at the following category of clients; 
i. New female clients who are economically active and require N500, 000 and above 
to fund their business.  
ii. Existing female regular and SBL clients who require more than N500, 000 to expand 
their business. 
 
13.4 BUSINESSES TO BE FUNDED 
i. Trade businesses with regular cash flow and all forms of legality 
ii. Service renderers with additional large scale trading business and regular cash 
flow. 
iii. Schools which are in their permanent site,  registered and government approved, 
with at least nursery and primary sessions. 
iv. Hospitals which are in their permanent site, registered and government approved, 
belonging to the person applying for the loan and with a dispensary.

13.5 CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
The following criteria qualify both new and existing clients for SUFEN loan: 
i. Client must  be a female entrepreneur who has been in business for at least one 
year with a regular cash flow 
ii. The age of the client shall be between 25 to 60 years at the time of application. 
iii. Existing LAPO clients who took 500.000 with excellent repayment history can 
obtain initial maximum loan of N700, 000. While new clients can obtain maximum 
of N500,000 
iv. Clients must have two (2) Credible Guarantors. 
v. Where clients are appraised and qualify for less than N500,000, the loan shall be 
disbursed as an SBL loan 
vi. On no account should less than N500, 000 be disbursed as SUFEN loan.  
vii. Client will be required to place a l ien on stock as a part of security for the loan 
using the deed of hypothecation document.  
viii. Client must have a verifiable business either in lock up shops, open shops, 
caravans, homes or any good selling shop that is sited in good location for the 
purpose of patronage from customers. 
ix. Client must have traded in that particular location for at least one year. 
x. Client must have been in a particular line of business for a minimum period of one 
year and with proven knowledge of the business 
xi. Start-ups or those intending to change their line of business are not qualified. 
xii. Client should have proper books of accounts with regular cash flow.  
xiii. Business owners must be able to proof the ownership of the business by providin g 
the business/site receipts or  other relevant bus iness documents, which MUST be 
in the name of the person applying for the loan, to authenticate their ownership 
xiv. Should be aged between 25 and 60 years 
xv. Service providers are not qualified unless  they also engage in  trading (sales) 
activities 
xvi. Start-ups are not qualified  
xvii. Suppliers must be land lords or landladies 
xviii. For Restaurant and bar, the location must be viable, the quality of food must be 
good and the quantity cooked daily should be worth up to N50, 000 at least. The 
person must also be involved in the sales of drinks.

13.10    OPERATIONAL METHODOLOGY 
i. Timeline for loan disbursement to a new client is maximum two weeks after 
account opening. 
ii. All loans must be fully repaid before a new loan can be disbursed. 
iii. Every loan stage is treated as a fresh loan and as such in -depth business appraisal 
must be carried out and approval based on current worth of business. 
iv. All subsequent loan stages must be appraised at most one week after full payment. 
v. Same day disbursement is equally possible if properly planned. 
vi. Credit committee MUST verify both house and business of client  
vii. Credit committee to also visit house and business of at least one guarantor. 
viii. After loan approval, clients MUST attend a one day pre-loan/business management 
training for three contact periods of two hours each before disbursement.

14.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO MfB –Progress Loan (PL) was developed to reward client loyalty, especially union leaders 
and secretaries. Progress Loan is financed with funds from Central Bank of Nigeri a, Micro Small 
and Medium Enterprise Development Fund (CBN MSMEDF). The objective of this fund is to 
finance businesses of entrepreneurs at the bottom of the pyramid, while LAPO MfB is poised at 
providing cheaper funds for her esteemed clients to reward client loyalty over the years.  
14.3   TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
The primary targets of the product are existing LAPO MfB clients, especially union leaders and 
secretaries. Also targeted are existing SBL/SUFEN clients with 100% repayment history.

i. Trade businesses with regular cash flow and all forms of legality 
ii. Manufacturing  
iii.   Production

unions/groups. Union members and ind ividual loan clients with 100% repa yment history are 
also eligible

vi. Individual clients (Leaders/Secretaries) can access the loan as their third running loan 
but the client’s total loan indebtedness to LAPO Microfinance Bank L imited should not 
be more than four hundred thousand naira (N400, 000).

15.2   PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO MfB –People with Disability loan (PWD) is designed to empower PWDs by granting 
them access to cheap funds rather than treat them as charity cases. By so doing they can 
reach their fullest potential and contribute greatly to the productivity and progress of the 
nation. PWD loan is financed with the 2% reserved funds from Central Bank of Nigeria, 
Micro Small and Medium Enterprise Development Fund (CBN MSMEDF).  
 
15.3   TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
The product targets economically viable Persons with Disability. 
 
15.4    BUSINESSES TO BE FUNDED 
 
a. Trade businesses with regular cash flow and all forms of legality 
b. Manufacturing  
c. Production 
15.5   CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
i. Shall be member of the association of people living with disability /recommended by 
CBN  
ii. Be between ages of twenty (27) to Sixty (60) years.  
iii. Present evidence of an existing business venture and permane nt office address 
required.  
iv. Present evidence of a permanent house address 
v. Create/Open account with LAPO MfB.  
vi. Be willing and committed to imbibe savings culture.  
vii. Be willing to provide one credible guarantor  (Guarantors are individuals with a good 
job/business and have the capacity that meet borrowers’ repayment oblig ations in 
the event of default; non shall be with disability) 
15.6   GUARANTORS ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA   
 
i. Guarantors must have enough repayment capacity to repay the loan in case of 
default. 
ii. Guarantors must be willing to repay the loan. 
iii. Business guarantors must have been in business for at least one year.  
iv. At least one out of the two parties to the loan should be married, i.e either the client 
or the guarantor.

and asset acquisition needs of salary earners. The product would not only improve their lives but also

Microfinance Bank while the specific objectives include:

iii. Increase their global competitiveness by inculcating in them global best business practices. 
iv. Make the participants creators of wealth and employer of labour, and for the future giving 
back to the parents (LAPO clients) of trainees and the society at large.

The loan was developed to meet the needs of churches/Mosque in the area of building 
construction and acquisition of assets such as: vehicles, musical instruments, public address 
systems, furniture and fittings etc.  This is in response to the yearnings of religious organizations 
with high volume of activities. 
 
19.3 TARGET MARKET 
Target market are Churches, Approved Units or groups in Churches.

i. Church MUST be registered with CAC. 
ii. Certificate of Incorporation and Church Constitution

premises visitation.

permanent site.

20.2 PRODUCT RATIONALE 
LAPO MfB – Housing loans is poised at availing both existing and new clients the opportunity to 
own their own homes at a more affordable interest rate. LAPO’s interest to develop this 
product is born out of her desire to enabl e clients build their own houses as a way  of also 
improving their lives. 
20.3 TARGET MARKET DEFINITION 
 LAPO MfB Housing Loan targets the following categories of clients; 
i. Staff of reputable organizations with fixed payday and regular salary structure. 
ii. Self-employed non -professionals like petty traders, shopkeepers, farm equipment traders, 
etc. 
iii. Self-employed non-professional service providers like hairdressers, mechanics, tailors etc. 
iv. Farmers. 
v. Can be existing or potential clients interested in housing loan. 
 
20.4 CLIENTS TO BE FUNDED 
 
i.   Staff of reputable organizations with fixed payday, regular salary structure and adequate 
repayment capacity to repay loan. 
ii.   Persons engaged in trade businesses with regular cash flow and all forms of legality

iii. Service renderers such as mechanics, tailors, salons, etc with regular cash flow. 
iv. Schools which may or may not be in their permanent site, but must be registered and 
government approved, with at least nursery and primary sessions. For clients not in their 
permanent site, the rent paid should cover the expected loan duration of the proposed loan. 
v.   Hospitals which may or may not be in their permanent site, registered and government 
approved, belonging to the person applying for the loan and with a dispensary. For clients n ot 
in their permanent site, the rent paid should cover the expected loan duration of the 
proposed loan. 
vi. All businesses on the LAPO MfB exclusion list are not eligible 
 
20.5 CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
i. Clients or potential clients must have unencumbered hou sing unit (and land) with valid 
documentation and willingness to improve the property. Documents certifying ownership of 
land could be only (original) Certificate of Occupancy or Deed of Transfer (with original 
supporting documents). 
ii. Clients or potential c lients must have an existing and viable business (or regular income from 
employment) with a cash flow that is robust enough to make for repayment of the loan. As a 
general rule, monthly repayment for housing loan CANNOT be more than 25% of client’s 
monthly income. 
iii. Monthly debt burden by client should not exceed 40% of client’s monthly income. For 
example, if potential client has already debt payment totaling 23% of monthly income, LAPO 
will estimate the allowable average monthly payment for this particular client to be 17% of 
monthly income (40%-23%). 
iv. Opening of savings account with minimum of N1, 000 for all new housing clients is required. 
New clients will have to operate their savings accounts for four weeks before a housing loan 
can be assessed. However, this will not be applicable to existing LAPO MFB clients. 
v. Clients that are salaried employees must have been employed by the current employer for 
more than one (1) year.  
vi. For clients that are self -employed, their business must be operational for at least one year. 
Evidence of such will be asked by CSO in the course of the appraisal. 
vii. The age of the applicant shall be between 25 to 60 years at the time of application. However, 
for civil servants with no other source of income, maximum age shall be 55 years. 
viii. Clients must attend a one -day pre-loan training session for proper orientation to all aspects 
of housing loan product. 
ix. Proof of payment of community and other dues 
x. Proof of ownership or legal use of property.   
xi. The original land title of the client is required. 
xii. Proof of 10% savings of approved loan amount

20.6 GUARANTORS ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA   
 
i. Guarantors must have enough repayment capacity to repay the loan in case of default. 
ii. Guarantors must be willing to repay the loan. 
iii. Guarantors must present one (1 ) undated cheque leaflet each as security for the loan on the 
day of disbursement (for loans of N1, 000,000 – N4, 000,000). 
iv. Business guarantors must have been in business for at least one year.  
v. At least two out of the three parties to the loan should be m arried, i.e either the client and 
one guarantor or the two guarantors, (where the client is not married) should be married. 
vi. Guarantors should either be working or doing business and preferably one family member 
and one family friend and should be willing a nd have capacity to repay the loan in the event 
of any default.  
vii. Situations where the business is jointly owned (as in the case of joint proprietorship) or jointly 
managed (as in the case of spouses) three guarantors will be required. 
viii. Situations where the spouse is not economically active, three guarantors will be required as 
the spouse will be the third guarantor to the loan. 
ix. Situations where the spouse is working or engaged in a business that is not jointly owned and 
verified to be separate from the business being used for loan assessment, two guarantors can 
be accepted.   
x. Guarantors must be aged between 25 and 60 years

20.8 PRODUCT OFFER 
 
This product can to be offered for two main purposes namely: Home Improvement  and Full House 
Construction. 
 
20.8.1 HOME IMPROVEMENT LOAN 
 
Any one or a combination of the following activities aimed at improving housing unit may be 
financed: 
i. Any alteration (both major and minor) in a fixed property intended by the client to be a 
permanent part of the house; that will enhance its durability and material value. Home 
improvements include, but are not limited to the following: 
a.  Any im provement or repair of any part of fixed dwelling propert y (e.g., replacing 
foundations)  
b. Installation or replacement of doors, roofs, floors, walls, windows, kitchen, and 
bathroom, painting, tiling, plastering, etc. 
c. “Productive housing” improvements or extensions related to a home-based enterprise 
or on-site production (e.g., adding rooms, building additional floors or annexes); 
d. Upgrading security and utilities (e.g., fencing or burglar bars, drainage and sinking 
Boreholes). 
e. Addition or extension of rooms, kitchens, toilets/bathrooms, floors, etc. 
ii. Costs related to minor construction/completion of a residential unit on a portion owned by 
the client’s household, including development, addition or extension of r ooms or housing 
units for rent. 
iii. It should be note d that purchase of furniture, appliances and electronic goods shall not be 
considered as home improvements under this context. 
 
 
20.8.2   FULL CONSTRUCTION HOUSING LOAN 
 
Building a new housing unit either in one or multiple stages (depending on client’s capacity)

safe. The register will be kept inside the safe as well.

20.14 OPERATIONAL METHODOLOGY- Step-By-Step Procedural Guide 
i. Marketing- Housing CSO visits market places, LAPO MFB unions, cooperatives, private and 
public      offices, etc. to market the product. 
 
ii. Screening- The CSO interviews the client to determine whether the client meets the eligibility 
requirements.  
 
iii. Account Opening - The CSO request clients to provide all documentation for opening of 
account; all required documents for opening of account will  be filled and account opened  
with N1, 000.  
 
iv. Application Letter- The client submits handwritten loan application letter. 
v. Application/Guarantors’ Form - CSO gives the client loan application form and guarantors’ 
form to fill. 
 
vi. Submission of Completed Forms - The client submits all completed forms with all required 
documents such as Land title (i.e. Deed of Agreeme nt, Deed of Transfer or C of O), Rent 
receipt, Utility bills, 3 months’ Pay slip, ID card, 6 months’ bank statement. 
 
 20.15 APPRAISAL 
 
CSO carries out the following appraisal procedures 
 
i. Validate the rightful owner of the land through documents/reference checks and site visits;  
 
ii. Interview the client about the purpose of the loan;  
iii. CSO visits the business/office, house location and carries out cash flow assessment to 
ascertain the repayment capacity of the client; and 
 
iv. CSO visits the guarantors’ business, office and house location to carry out cash flow 
assessment to ascertain their financial strength. 
v. Technical Assistant (TA) - The TA visits the site to carry out feasibility study and estimates the 
construction cost in stages to completion. After which a B ill of Quantity (BoQ) will be 
prepared and sent to the Branch Manager (BM). 
vi. Verification - A member of the Credit Committee or CSO verifies the documents by visiting 
the site, business, and office and house location of the client.

vii. Loan Approval - The CSO prepares loan file for Credit Committee meeting after    verification. 
Credit Committee approves postpones or rejects the client’s application. CSO then informs the 
client of their decision. 
 
20.16 DISBURSEMENT 
 
The following steps should be followed; 
i. The CSO informs the TA about the disbursement.  
ii. The CSO prepares the Loan Agreement Form.  
iii. The client c omes to the office with one or two credible guarantors. (depending on the loan 
size) 
iv. The client deposits the processing and insurance fees to branch or depository bank. 
v. On the day disbursement, client comes with the material dealers. 
vi. The CSO and Credit Committee members’ safe keep the documents. 
vii. The Branch Accountant (BA) prepares  cheque in the name of material/d ealers and for client 
for non-material expenses. 
viii. The Data Entry Staff enters client’s information into Orbit-R. 
ix. The CSO prints the repayment schedule from Orbit-R and provides to client. 
 
20.16.1    DISBURSEMENT PROCEDURE 
 
i. Upon approval of the loan, proceeds for material (based on construction specialist ’s 
specification) will be disbursed to various material dis tributors as selected by the client , while 
the remainder of proceeds will be placed (for the short time) in client’s account at LAPO, and 
will be available for clients to withdrew in stages based o n other construction costs (labour, 
water, electricity, tools, equipment, etc.). However, withdrawals will be made only upon 
client produce a proof of expense in form of invoice for services, utilities, or tools. 
ii. This disbursement to distributors will be p roposed to the client after loan assessment. The 
client will have a period of five (5) working days to make a counter -proposal on distribu tors 
after the formal proposal by the technical assistance. 
iii. Housing loan will be provided to individuals, using Cash f low based lending methodology for 
client appraisal; approved loan amount will be subject to the client’s repayment capacity. 
 
20.17 LOAN UTILIZATION MONITORING 
 
i. The CSO will take a picture of the house or land before loan disbursement and maximum one 
(1) week after loan disbursement to ensure disbursed loan has been efficiently utilized for the 
loan purpose.

20.18 REPAYMENT 
i. After disbursement, loan repayment schedule will be printed and han ded over to the    client,

and teller submitted at the branch to enable the branch staff update the passbook. 
 
20.19 OPERATIONAL METHODOLOGY 
 
i. Timeline for loan disbursement to a new client is maximum four weeks after account opening. 
ii. All loans must be fully repaid before a new loan can be disbursed. 
iii. Every loan stage is treat ed as a fresh loan and as such in -depth business appraisal must be 
carried out and approval based on current worth of business. 
iv. All subsequent loan stages must be appraised at most one week after full payment. 
v. Same day disbursement is equally possible if properly planned. 
vi. Credit committee MUST verify both house and business of client  
vii. Credit committee to also visit house and business of at least one guarantor. 
viii. After loan approval, clients MUST attend a one-day pre-loan training 
ix. Pre-loan training notebook to  be opened in branches to document the names of clients who 
attend the training. This note is to be kept by the manager 
x. On NO ACCOUNT should any of these pre -loan training classes be waived for any client as 
attendance is COMPULSORY. 
 
20.20 LOAN CLASSIFICATION 
Housing loan can be classified into two; 
i. CLASS 1: This refers to housing loans between N100, 000 to N99 0, 000. This class of loans can 
be accessed by new clients and existing clients of other LAPO MFB products.

20.21 PROCEDURE FOR COLLATERAL VALUATION IN HOUSING LOAN 
In property valuation doctrine, all buildings deprec iate as a result of physical obsolescence, 
functional obsolescence and economic obsolescence. It is the responsibility of the CSO  to 
determine what kind of obsolescence that has beset the subject property. But on physical 
obsolescence alone, there are fu ndamental principles guiding his or her  choice of rate to 
apply on a property to reflect the depreciation value. 
The following shall serve as guide to the CSO when valuing collateral for housing loan.

24.0 Public Sector Personal Loan (PSPL)                          
24.1 Introduction 
LAPO Public Sector Per sonal Loan is a product that offers personal loans through Payroll Lending to 
Civil Servants at the State and Federal levels. PSPL is deduction -based, as repayments due to LAPO 
Microfinance Bank Ltd are deducted at source before salary payments are made to  obligors. Such 
deductions are now remitted to LAPO MFB within a specified period through her Correspondent 
Bank as communicated to the Accountant General Office/State Treasury Office (STO).  LAPO Public 
Sector Personal Loan is for State Government employe es. Because of its peculiarity and market 
dynamics (competition), beneficiaries are not required to open a formal account with the Bank. It is 
simply a payroll based lending of which LAPO MfB shall have first priority over the applicant’s 
monthly salary before the resulting net balance is transmitted to the domiciled Bank Account of the 
applicant. LAPO’s successful acquisition of the Oracle Salary Access Deduction Code is a perfect 
security for the loan exposures to the Civil Servants. It guarantees 100% co llections with high credit 
quality.

No personal Guarantor is required for t his loan, however, with the acquisition of LAPO’s PS Salary

24.2.6 PSPL Operational Guidelines  
1. The first step of the loan creation process is the completion of Loan Application/Agreement Form 
obtainable at any of LAPO MfB Branches or through PS Relationship Officers (ROs).  
2. The completed Loan Application Form/Agreement is reviewed and verified by the Relationship 
Officer for correctness. 
3. In calculating the monthly installment, we should take into consideration the fees payment 
option (upfront deduction or capitalized) chosen by the customer. By upfront, the fees are 
deducted from the approved loan before crediting applicant’s account while capitalization means 
adding the fees to the principal amount and spreading it over the loan tenor. This is the preferred 
option for the clients.  Below is the guide for these calculations: 
- Capitalize Option: 
o Fees Amount = Fees Rate X Amount approved 
o Monthly Principal = {Amount approved + Fee Amount}/ Tenor of the Loan 
- Monthly Installment = Monthly Interest + Monthly Principal 
4. The completed Loan Agreement form is submitted to the Data Entry Staff/Loan Processor for the 
first-level review (Operations) 
5. The DES carries out the preliminary screening and reviews the necessary documentation for 
authenticity and completeness. 
6. The DES initiates the loan request on the Bank’s Core Banking Application Software – Orbit-R. 
Amongst other things, the DES should specifically; 
i. Confirm if the customer’s face on passport photo matches the ID card.

24.3.11 Loan Repayment Procedures    
All the Public Sector Personal Loans shall be deducted at source, hence, 100% repayment is expected.  
i. Customers’ repayments are made through their Oracle Number (the unique identifier for all 
Lagos State Civil Servants).

Correspondent Bank account.

should be Noted that the first loan deduction shall occur a month after disbursement.

24.3.12 Loan Monitoring          
Loan monitoring shall be supervised by the Accounts/Reconciliation Officer using automated reports 
generated from the Core Banking Software (CBS). The review entails loan classification in accordance 
with Prudential Guidelines standards viz: 
i. Performing Loan – a loan is classified as performing if there is no due and unpaid portion of 
principal and /or interest.  
ii. Past and watch-list – when a due portion of the principal and/or interest of a loan remains unpaid 
between 1 and 30days, such loan is classified as past and watch-list 
iii. Sub-standard – This describes facilities that have due and unpaid portion of principal and/or 
interest between 31 and 60 days 
iv. Doubtful – Doubtful describes facilities with due and unpaid portion of principal and/or interest 
between 61 – 90days 
v. Lost – If a portion of the loan principal/and or interest remains unpaid for more than 90days, the 
loan shall be classified as lost!  
Note: Loans classified as sub -standard, doubtful and lost are said to be delinquent and are called 
“non-performing loan”. 
 
24.3.13 Loan Provisioning 
Loan provisioning shall be as follows: 
i. Performing Loans: General provision of 1% of the loan principal outstanding. 
ii. Past and watch-list: Provisioning of 5% of the loan principal outstanding 
iii. Substandard: Provisioning of 25% of the loan principal outstanding 
iv. Doubtful: Provisioning of 50% of the loan principal outstanding  
v. Lost: Provisioning of 100% of the loan principal outstanding 
Note: Although a 100% loan repayment is expected on this product, it is an industry wide standard to 
have these policies in place. 
  
24.3.14   Loan delinquency prevention and management  
LAPO’s PSPL shall adopt a Zero toler ance for loan delinquency. However, incidences of salary delays, 
retirement, resignation, death etc., of the employee could lead to late repayment which is not 
necessarily a default per se as any past due obligation is recoverable.  
Below are some of the steps to prevent and manage PSPL delinquency: 
i. Monitoring of clients :  loan repayment should be monitored and whenever a customer delays 
(due to our internal processes), action should be taken to remedy it. Proper monitoring should be

ii. Continuous loan appraisal: this is a critical lending process. It involves the methods of collecting

iii. Proper client selection: When granting a loan, proper procedures, rules and regulations must be

iii. The approval is forwarded to the Operations Head for implementation.

25.0 Edu Finance Loan Product (School Fees and School Improvement Loans) 
25.1 Background Information 
LAPO MfB in the quest to broaden its commitment to the education sector in Nigeria partnered with 
Opportunity International (OI) in the latter’s flagship EduFinance Project. The OI Edufinance project is 
mainly targeted at increasing access t o quality education for children in low to middle income 
countries by providing Technical Assistance to financial institutions in building profitable education 
lending portfolios.  The financial institution’s intervention therefore increases funding opport unities 
for financially constrained private schools and the parents of the children that attend them to meet 
the needs for quality education. Thus, the outcome of the market research by Opportunity 
International and other technical supports led to the development of this Loan Products. 
25.2 Objective 
To cater for private school owners and parents who are willing to provide quality education for their 
children but are constrained by lack of access to responsible and affordable financial intermediations.   
25.3 Challenges of Financing Education 
1. Inability of parents to finance their children’s education. 
2. Location of school too far for the pupil/students. 
3. Engagement of children into child labour/illicit acts in order to meet up with school expenses.  
4. High teachers’ absenteeism due to inability of schools to meet their needs. 
5. Lack of teaching materials/amenities. 
6. High Failure rate. 
 
25.4 Target Clients 
1. Private school owners desirous of responsible and affordable financial intermediations for the 
provision of quality education; and 
2. Households with stable income and that are willing to educate their children in private 
schools at the Primary and Secondary levels. 
 
Note 1. Mega and Super Branches can offer both School Fees and School 
Improvement Loan, while Regular Br anches can only offer School Fees 
Loan. 
2. Trained Individual Loan CSOs can only process and manage a maximum 
loan request of N5m.

25.6 Operational Guidelines for School Fees Loan 
25.6.1 Eligibility and Basic Requirements 
1. It is available to Group Customers. 
2. Applicants could be parent of Pupils and students in primary or secondary school respectively; 
students in vocational/technical schools (above 18years) with income generating act ivities. 
Justification capacity and willingness to repay the loan would also be considered. 
3. Be a client of LAPO MFB.  
4. New clients are eligible to assess the product. 
5. Applicants must be above 18 years and not more than 65 years old for Traders and Business 
Owners. For Salary Earners in a structure private organization, he/she should not be more 
than 60 years.   
6. Loan can be disbursed to Civil servants in states with Proof of Regular salary payment. 
7. Client must have children or dependents of school age. 
8. Client’s child/dependent (beneficiary) must not participate in child labour. Monitoring of child 
labour would be carried out by Inspectors who pays unannounced visits to the child’s school, 
check attendance as well as visit client’s workplace where the child is likely to be engaged in 
child labour. The Inspector will forward report to Client Relationship Managers (CRMs) at the 
Zonal Levels for onward rendition to Strategy Group at Lagos Annex. 
9. Clients should be encouraged to participate in LAPO MfB savings products. 
10. A completed Loan Application Form is compulsory. 
11. The completed Loan Application Form must be submitted with the following documents: 
Income-related documentation (like pay slips, account statement); School admission letter; 
School requirement letter to justify requested amount. 
 
25.6.2 Operational Guidelines for School Fees Loan 
1. LAPO MFB directly pays the school fees so client doesn’t have to receive the loan and pay the 
school or alternatively to client’s savings account. 
Where the client needs to purc hase books and other items personally; then only tuition fees 
will be credited to the school’s account; however, this should be verified from the school 
requirement letter. 
2. Approval will be given by the credit committee for SME, Mega and Super branches whi le 
Branch Managers will approve for regular branches. 
3. When client has paid off the loan, he/she can automatically be entitled to a new loan when 
new school fees are due however, they will need to provide the school requirement letter for 
the new period.

25.7.1 Eligibility and Basic Requirements 
1. Clients within the proximity of the branch network. 
2. Nationality of Proprietor/Partners/Key person(s) of company must be Nigerian. 
3. Owned as private limited company, trust-managed, church-owned, partnership or sole 
proprietorship or community owned. 
4. Possess a valid operating license from relevant authorities. 
5. The Establishment/School must have operated for at least 1 year. 
6. The school must be with at least 100 learners (Exception: Schools in Lagos – minimum 50 
students/ schools with at least 2 years of positive historical performance and growth).  
7. The net increase for at least a session (i.e. per term) should be considered. 
8. Opening a School Current Account through which the transactions shall be made both by the 
school and the bank, channeling school fees deposi ts through the school account 
(fundamental for a continued relationship with LAPO MFB). 
9. The school or college should have banking history with LAPO MfB or another financial 
institution and have at least basic record keeping and/or accounting services. 
10. Evidence of proper records. Having a proper management information system will be a plus. 
11. Other Conditions that determine the maximum amount of loan accessible by the school are 
as follows:  
i. N2,000,000 maximums for Schools with provisional registration/approval with incomplete 
or insufficient business record. 
ii. N2,000,000 maximums for fully registered schools with incomplete or insufficient 
business record. 
iii. Amounts above N2,000,000 for fully registered/approved schools with complete and 
sufficient business records. 
12. List of Excluded schools or Borrowers 
i. Schools being run in a non -friendly way to both natural environment and humans. For 
example, by encroaching on swamps or cutting down forests. 
ii. Schools with no track record of operation/experience of at least 2 years. 
iii. Schools operating illegally (without permission from the relevant authorities).

1. Certificate of Incorporation by the CAC, License and/or Certificate of Registration from the 
Ministry of Education. 
2. ID Document and business records and/ or transaction receipts for the past 12 months. . 
3. Rent receipt for at least 6 months or Lease Agreement (if applicable). 
4. Detailed budget with time schedule for building extension (where applicable). 
5. Bills, invoice or quote from the vendor regarding fixed assets purchase and building extension 
project (where applicable).

25.8 School Improvement Operational Procedure 
25.8.1 Marketing, Screening Procedure 
1. Client Support Officer (CSO) visits private schools to market the various Edu -finance School 
Improvement Products (Marketing). 
2. The CSO interviews the school proprietor/tress to determine whether the client meets the 
eligibility requirements (Screening). 
3. The CSO request the school to provide all documentation for opening of current account; all 
required documents for opening of account will be filled and account opened. 
 
25.8.2 Loan Disbursement Procedure 
1. School identification by CSO to ascertain if risk assessme nt criteria of Education Lending 
Product are met, if yes proceed to 2; otherwise communicate decision to intending obligor. 
2. CSO request the school to fill an application form. Once completed and confirmed, the CSO 
carries out the following appraisal procedures: 
i. Validate the rightful owner of the land through documents/reference checks and 
site visits; 
ii. Interview the client about the purpose of the loan; 
iii. Visits the business/office, house location and carries out cash flow assessment to 
ascertain the repayment capacity of the client; 
iv. Visits the guarantors’ business, office and house location to carry out cash flow 
assessment to ascertain their financial strength;

BM/Team Lead who reviews the school’s request and all submitted do cuments and

25.8.3 Loan Repayment Methodology 
1. All loans must be repaid within the agreed repayment date.  
2. Both Interest and principal are paid quarterly and or termly. 
3. The Client (School) must provide post-dated cheques covering the loan repayment period. 
4. Cheques must be presented as they fall due by HOP or Cash Officer with a follow up from the 
CSO and Credit Administrator. 
5. Direct Debit mandates must be done as at when due. 
6. Payment into Bank’s corresponding account is acceptable with proof of payment must be 
submitted to the BA. 
7. Staff are prohibited from handling cash, therefore clients who desires to pay before due date 
are to either make direct transfer or cash lodgment into Branch correspondent account with 
evidence of payment forwarded to the CSO.  
8. On no account should any staff give personal bank account number to clients for the purpose 
of repayment or any official transaction.  
9. Clients should be advised to always provide proof of payments for updates after any transaction. 
10. Any loan repayment that is paid after 4pm should be boxed for the next day’s transaction. 
 
25.8.4 Loan Monitoring  
1. The first Monitoring Officer to the loan is the CSO/RM and the BM. 
2. Credit Committee/Administrator major role is to ensure quality of loan in addition to driving 
businesses for actualization of set target. 
3. CSO/RM must visit school premises within one week of disbursement to ensure loan is not 
diverted and subsequently, once in every month with visit status update submitted to the 
Credit Administrator. This report shall form part of their monthly report to the Head office. 
4. For Fixed Asset Loans, vendor must be confirmed by the CSO/Credit Administrator. Authority 
to pay must be issued by the client for either a Bank draft or direct disbursement in favor of 
the vendor.  This is to check possible diversion of loan proceeds.

3. Provide suitable guarantors to guarantee the loan as required. 
4. Provide collateral as may be required for the loan. 
5. Make good the facility in line with terms and condition as specified in the offer letter and loan 
agreement.  
6. Fund his or her account with initial cash deposit as requested and stated in the offer letter.  
7. Ensure his or her account is adequately funded to meet repayment as they fall due.  
8. Fund his or her account with all cost that might arise in the course of loan processing.  
9. Provision of Secondary Account Details and Biometric Verification Number (BVN) of new 
obligors and returning clients. 
 
25.8.6 Loan Liquidation, Interest Waiver Procedure  
1. Clients are allowed to liquidate their loan anytime at no additional cost.  
2. Interest will not be waived for those that pay their loan rental in advance. 
3. Existing facility which will be liquidated into the new loan amount with the difference made 
available for client to draw. 
4. Any client intending to pay off must notify the CSO, who must advise the client of his or her 
outstanding. The client must settle on the advised balance within 10 days of notification. 
5. Should clients not settle within the month of advice, client must pay the interest for the new 
month.  
6. All requests for Interest waiver must be approved by the BM.  
7. The BM, HOP and ICO must ensure clients’ account or branch correspondent bank account is 
adequately funded. Compliance officer must certify this transaction before it is carried out. 
8. Every eligible client is entitled to interest waiver.

25.10 Risk Profile for School Fees Loan- Tertiary Product 
1. Exposure of the bank to new customers/new target market segments whose credit behavior 
is yet to be understood.  
2. Exposure of the Bank to a customer segment/product more likely to default. 
3. Exposure of the bank to credit risk/default where the student absconds or unable to gain 
employment upon graduation. 
4. Likelihood of loan diversion by the loan beneficiary when the amount requested for the 
academic session is disbursed once. 
 
25.10.1 Mitigation of Identified Risks 
1. The bank has decided to run a pilot for a minimum period of twelve (12) months to study and 
observe clients credit behavior and performance of the loan.  
2. The Bank Management through its risk management oversight function shall set internal 
thresholds limit for loan portfolio distribution and loan loss ratio for this product which will be 
monitored stringently. 
3. The loan beneficiary (student) must exceed the minimum age limit of 18 years, have an active 
bank account with valid Bank Verification Number. 
4. Staggered loan disbursement per session into the school correspondent bank account. 
5. Transfer of the risk of loss of job, disability, death of the loan beneficiary to the insurance 
company.  
6. The maximum loan duration for loans disbursed under this initiative shall be 12 months.

26.0 WHOLESALE LENDING PRODUCT 
26.1 CONCEPT OF WHOLESALE LENDING PRODUCT 
26.1.1   INTRODUCTION 
Wholesale Micro Loan product is designed to meet the funding gaps of microfinance institutions, 
cooperatives, associations and organized groups whose scope of business is geared towards financial 
inclusion. This product enables LAPO Microfinance bank support the businesses of microfinance 
institutions to deepen their penetrations to the diverse unbanked individuals in Nigeria.  
26.1.2   PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVE 
The purpose and objective of this product is to further promote the Bank’s mission and vision 
statement of improving lives; through creating a stable and sustainable funding access to formal 
institutions towards meeti ng their core mandate of funding Micro, Small and medium enterprises 
(MSMEs). 
26.2   BENEFITS OF WHOLESALE MICROFINANCE LOAN 
1. Portfolio diversification for the bank 
2. Reliable source of funding for the beneficiary institutions.  
3. Create a new market for the bank 
4. Improve the lending capacity of retail microfinance and other lending institutions  
5.  Increase the Bank’s profitability by increasing borrower base 
26.3    TARGET MARKET 
- NGOs microfinance institutions 
- Cooperatives,  
- Associations, 
- Organized Groups 
26.4   STRATEGY FOR DEPLOYMENT 
The Bank will identify approved institutions through their umbrella bodies and market scanning.

26.6    OPERATIONAL PROCESSES AND PROCEDURE  
The following processes and procedure shall be followed in the management of this product. 
 
26.6.1 OPERATIONAL METHODOLOGY 
i. The disbursement of this loan product shall be based on individual / cash flow based methodology.  
ii. All businesses must the appraised using the cash flow methodology to analyze the worth and size of 
the business in order to determine the repayment capacity of such business. 
iii. Timeline for loan disbursement to a new customer is maximum one week after due diligence 
and every necessary document has been submitted by the customer.  
iv. All loans must be fully repaid before a new loan can be disbursed. 
v. Every loan stage is treated as a fresh loan and as such in-depth business appraisal must be 
carried out and approval based on current worth of business

each in addition to a  floating charge of 150% of amount to be disbursed on all customer’s 
assets (Including loan portfolio) 
iv. Customer must be between the age 20- 75 years  
v. Customer must be able to provide the business records for verification to determine the 
number of customers they have and the business capacity.

27.0 LOW-COST HOUSING INTERVENSION LOAN PRODUCT 
 
Partnership with  Millard Fuller Foundation, Luvu, Masaka, Nasarawa on low -cost 
housing intervention 
 
Housing Intervention loan is an initiative by Millard Fuller Foundation in bid to provide 
intermediations for prospective low-income earners who are the targeted off -takers of Millard’s low-
cost houses developed. 
The loan product aims to make available affordable credit to interested customers in building houses

cycles.

27.5 CLIENT ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
i. Clients or potential clients must have unencumbered housing unit (and land) with valid 
documentation and willingness to impro ve the property. Documents certifying 
ownership of land could be only (original) Certificate of Occupancy or Deed of Transfer 
(with original supporting documents). 
ii. Clients or potential clients must have an existing and viable business (or regular income 
from employment) with a cash flow that is robust enough to make for repayment of 
the loan. As a general rule, monthly repayment for housing loan CANNOT be more than 
25% of client’s monthly income. 
iii. Monthly debt burden by client should not exceed 40% of client ’s monthly income. For 
example, if potential client has already debt payment totaling 23% of monthly income, 
LAPO will estimate the allowable average monthly payment for this particular client to 
be 17% of monthly income (40%-23%). 
iv. Opening of savings accou nt with minimum of N1, 000 for all new housing clients is 
required. New clients will have to operate their savings accounts for four weeks before 
a housing loan can be assessed. However, this will not be applicable to existing LAPO 
MFB clients. 
v. Clients that are salaried employees must have been employed by the current employer 
for more than one (1) year.  
vi. For clients that are self -employed, their business must be operational for at least one 
year. Evidence of such will be asked by CSO in the course of the appraisal. 
vii. The age of the applicant shall be between 25 to 60 years at the time of application. 
However, for civil servants with no other source of income, maximum age shall be 55 
years. 
viii. Clients must attend a one -day pre -loan training session for proper ori entation to all 
aspects of housing loan product. 
ix. Proof of payment of community and other dues 
x. Proof of ownership or legal use of property.   
xi. The original land title of the client is required. 
xii. Proof of 10% savings of approved loan amount   
 
27.6 GUARANTORS ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA   
i. Guarantors must have enough repayment capacity to repay the loan in case of default. 
ii. Guarantors must be willing to repay the loan. 
iii. Guarantors must present one (1) undated cheque leaflet each as security for the loan 
on the day of disbursement (for loans of N1, 000,000 – N4, 000,000). 
iv. Business guarantors must have been in business for at least one year.  
v. At least two out of the three parties to the loan should be married, i.e either the client 
and one guarantor or the two guarantors, (where  the client is not married) should be 
married.

and one family friend and should be willing and have capacity to repay the loan in the event

vi. Situations where the business is jointly owned (as in the case of joint proprietorship) or jointly 
managed (as in the case of spouses) three guarantors will be required. 
vii. Situations where the spouse is not economically active, three guarantors will be required as

iv. Means of Identification (international passport, driver’s license, national identity 
card, voter s registration card, current university or polytechnic student identity 
card or notary public). For individuals without the above, Market Association 
identity cards or reference by at least two (2) account holders with valid means of 
identification may be accepted. Management may decide from time to time on 
acceptable means of identification depending on business exigency 
v. Utility bill of residence such as electricity bill, Refuse Disposal bill, Water supply bill. 
 
           43.3        REQUIREMENTS FOR CORPORATE CLIENTS  
i. Duly completed SID account opening form

sighted) 
viii. Original letter on official letter headed paper of the company appointing and 
 authorising the opening of account and appointing signatories and signing limits 
ix. Means of identification for each signatory 
x. Utility bill of business place 
 
 43.4        Authorisation 
i. Duly completed verification report. 
ii. Duly completed KYC procedure. 
iii. Confirm that amount is not below minimum deposit amount.
